## Selecta Group B.V.
### €150,000,000 Senior Secured Notes due 2024 consisting of € 5 [7]⁄ 8% Senior Secured Notes due 2024 € Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2024

Selecta Group B.V., a private limited liability company incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) € million in aggregate
principal amount of its 5 [7]⁄ 8% Senior Secured Notes due 2024 (the “Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes”) and € million in aggregate principal amount of its Senior Secured Floating
Rate Notes due 2024 (the “Additional Floating Rate Notes” and together with the Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the “Additional Notes”). The Additional Notes will be issued under
the indenture dated February 2, 2018, as amended and supplemented from time to time (the “Indenture”), governing, inter alia, the Issuer’s existing €765,000,000 5 [7]⁄ 8% Senior Secured
Notes due 2024 (the “Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes”), €325,000,000 Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes due 2024 (the “Existing Floating Rate Notes”), and CHF 250,000,000 5 [7]⁄ 8%
Senior Secured Notes due 2024 (the “CHF Notes” and together with the Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes and the Existing Floating Rate Notes, the “Existing Notes”; the Existing Notes
together with the Additional Notes, the “Notes”). The Additional Notes will have the same ISIN and common codes as their respective series of Existing Notes, provided that the Additional
Notes sold outside the United States pursuant to Regulation S of the U.S. Securities Act (the “Regulation S Additional Notes”) will initially be issued bearing a temporary ISIN and common
code. On and from the consolidation date (the day which is 40 days after the later of the date of the original issuance of such Regulation S Additional Notes and the last date on which we or
any of our affiliates were the owner of Regulation S Additional Notes), the Regulation S Additional Notes will be consolidated and fully fungible with the Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes or
the Existing Floating Rate Notes, as applicable, sold outside the United States pursuant to Regulation S. See “Description of the Notes.”
The Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes will bear interest at a rate of 5 [7]⁄ 8%. The Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes will mature on February 1, 2024. The Issuer will pay interest on the
Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes semi-annually in arrears on October 1 and April 1, commencing on April 1, 2020. Interest on the Additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes will be deemed to have
accrued from October 1, 2019, with the interest accrued between October 1, 2019 and the Issue Date forming part of the Issue Price (as described below). The Additional Euro Fixed Rate
Notes (together with the Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes, the “Euro Fixed Rate Notes”) will have the same terms and conditions as the Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes and will constitute a
single class with the Existing Euro Fixed Rate Notes for all purposes under the Indenture, including, without limitation, waivers, amendments, redemptions and offers to purchase. Prior to
February 1, 2020, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes by paying a “make-whole” premium. At any time on or after February 1,
2020, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). In addition, prior to
February 1, 2020, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes issued)
with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings so long as at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Euro Fixed Rate
Notes), as the case may be, issued under the Indenture remain outstanding. Prior to February 1, 2020, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Euro Fixed
Rate Notes issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes issued) in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal
amount thereof.
The Additional Floating Rate Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to three-month EURIBOR plus 5.375% per annum, reset quarterly, and will mature on February 1, 2024. The Issuer
will pay interest on the Additional Floating Rate Notes quarterly in arrears on each of April 1, July 1, October 1 and January 2, commencing on January 2, 2020. Interest on the Additional
Floating Rate Notes will be deemed to have accrued from October 1, 2019, with the interest accrued between October 1, 2019 and the Issue Date forming part of the Issue Price (as described
below). The Additional Floating Rate Notes (together with the Existing Floating Rate Notes, the “Floating Rate Notes”) will have the same terms and conditions as the Existing Floating
Rate Notes and will constitute a single class with the Existing Floating Rate Notes for all purposes under the Indenture, including, without limitation, waivers, amendments, redemptions and
offers to purchase. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Floating Rate Notes at any time at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum.
Additionally, upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control or upon certain asset sales, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the Notes. A change of
control, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments
affecting taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in
aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender
offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain
outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”
The Additional Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is expressly subordinated in right of
payment to the Notes and will rank pari passu in right of payment with the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Existing
Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein). The Additional Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by AB Servicios Selecta España SLU, Acorn Spain 1 SLU,
Gruppo Argenta S.p.A., Pelican Rouge Coffee Roasters B.V., Selecta AB, Selecta AG, Selecta Belgium N.V., Selecta Nordic Holding AB, Selecta Holding SAS, Selecta Netherlands B.V.,
Selecta SAS, Selecta TMP AG, Selecta U.K. Limited and Selecta UK Holding Limited (each a “Guarantor” and collectively, the “Guarantors”). The Guarantors also guarantee, on a senior
basis, the obligations under the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. The Guarantees (as defined herein) will rank senior in right of payment to the respective Guarantor’s future
debt that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantee and will rank pari passu in right of payment with the respective Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not so
subordinated, including such Guarantor’s obligations under the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.
The Additional Notes will be secured on the Issue Date by the Collateral (as defined herein), which also secures the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. The Revolving
Credit Facility is subject to the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein) and, along with future hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a priority
basis under the Indenture, is secured by first-priority security interests over the Collateral, contractually ranking pari passu with the security interests securing the Additional Notes. Under
the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of enforcement of the security interests over the Collateral, holders of Additional Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only
after the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a priority basis under the Indenture, if any, have been repaid in full.
The validity, enforceability and, in respect of the security interests over the Collateral, priority and ranking of the Guarantees and the security interests and the liability of the Guarantors, are
subject to the limitations described in “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.” The
Additional Notes will be structurally subordinated to all obligations of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Additional Notes and effectively subordinated to any existing and
future debt of the Issuer and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Additional Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets.
This Offering Memorandum includes more detailed information on the terms of the Additional Notes and the Guarantees, including redemption and repurchase prices, security,
covenants, events of default and transfer restrictions.
Application will be made to the International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Additional Notes on the Official List of
The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance, however, that the Additional Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission

these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point

(10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II; or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 (the

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain unaudited financial data for the twelve months ended

**Segment Reporting and Revenue by Business Channel**

Throughout this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial and other data by geographic segment
and business channel.

**_Geographic Segments_**

We report our revenue and certain other financial data by geographic segment. The geographic segments in
which we operate correspond to our reporting segments under IFRS and consist of the following for the year
ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019:

   - _South, UK & Ireland includes operating entities in Ireland, Italy, Spain and the UK;_

   - _Central includes operating entities in Austria, France, Germany, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland; and_

   - _North includes operating entities in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands,_
Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2017, one operating entity in Finland was classified as held for
sale and excluded from this segment; it was subsequently sold in March 2018.

In addition to the segments identified above, we report separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which includes
corporate center functions in Switzerland and certain functions of former Pelican Rouge entities in the
Netherlands and in the UK.

x


-----

For comparative purposes, we also presented our revenue and certain other financial data for the year ended
September 30, 2017, in line with the above geographic segments in our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements.

For the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, we reported our revenue by the following geographic
segments:

   - _France included operating entities in France;_

   - _West included operating entities in Belgium, Ireland, the Netherlands and the UK;_

   - _Central included operating entities in Austria, Germany, Spain, and Switzerland; and_

   - _North included operating entities in Denmark, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, and_
Sweden. As of October 1, 2016, operating entities in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania were classified as
held for sale and excluded from this segment; they were subsequently sold in March 2017.

In addition to the segments identified above, we reported separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which
included corporate center functions in Switzerland.

**_Business Channels_**

We also report our revenue and certain other financial data by business channel. Our business channels
consist of the following for the year ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and
2019:

   - The workplace channel, which includes revenue from (i) private self-service retail, consisting of PoS
placed and serviced in various private locations, such as large corporate customers, in various
businesses and industries and including in corporate offices, manufacturing and logistics sites, and
(ii) OCS, which is comprised of table-top coffee machines rented out to corporate customers (mainly
small and medium-sized enterprises) for office use along with the provision of technical services and
coffee and related supplies for the PoS;

   - The on-the-go channel, which includes revenue from PoS placed and serviced in semi-public areas,
such as hospitals, universities and entertainment venues, or public areas, such as train stations, airports
and gas stations, following a successful bidding process with relevant government authorities to place
our PoS in a given location; and

   - The trading channel, which includes revenue from sales of machines and products, including coffee
roasted in our roasting facility and the provision of technical and hygienic support to customers.

We did not report our revenue by the above business channels in our financial statements for prior periods,
including for the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017. However, for comparative purposes, we presented
our revenue for the year ended September 30, 2017, by business channels in our 2018 Consolidated Financial
Statements.

**Non-GAAP Financial Information**

**_Non-GAAP Financial Measures_**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-GAAP measures and ratios, including EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin, gross
capital expenditures, net capital expenditures, revenue net of vending fee, and other measures and ratios that are
not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. We use these non-GAAP measures to help evaluate
growth trends, assess operational performance and monitor cash performance. We believe that presenting these
non-GAAP measures is useful to investors in evaluating our financial performance. We present non-GAAP
measures because we believe that they and similar measures are widely used by certain investors, securities
analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. The non-GAAP
measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as
analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as
reported under IFRS.

We define our non-GAAP measures as follows:

   - “Adjusted Cash Capital Expenditures (CS & CC)” consists of Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures
(CS & CC), net of finance lease inflows to Selecta, Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending,
adjusted at constant currency;

xi


-----

- “Adjusted EBIT (CS & CC)” represents our Adjusted EBITA (CS & CC) less Adjusted Amortization
(excluding purchase price allocation) (CS & CC) and purchase price allocation amortization. See
“Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”;

- “Adjusted EBITA (CS & CC)” represents our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) less Adjusted
Depreciation (CS & CC). See “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”;

- “Adjusted EBITDA” represents profit/(loss) before net finance results and income tax, before
(i) depreciation, (ii) amortization expense, (iii) restructuring/redundancy costs, (iv) project expenses,
(v) transaction and integration expenses, (vi) (profit)/loss on sale of subsidiaries, (vii) financing
activities, and (viii) other adjustments, as described further in “Summary—Summary Historical
_Financial and Other Information—Historical Consolidated Financial Information—Other Financial_
_Data and Operating Information”;_

- “Adjusted EBITDA margin” represents Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue net of vending
fee; we present Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of revenue net of vending fee because we believe
that it is useful to investors in evaluating our financial performance as it takes into account the impact
of vending fee on our revenue;

- “Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)” represents our EBITDA on a constant scope and constant currency
basis after giving effect to certain management adjustments. See “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated
_Financial Information” for a reconciliation of EBITDA to Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for each_
period presented;

- “Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margin” represent Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) as a percentage of
Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC) (as defined below);

- “Adjusted Gross Capital Expenditures (CS & CC)” represents our capital expenditures on a constant
scope and constant currency basis. See “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”;

- “Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS & CC)” consists of the Adjusted Gross Capital Expenditures
(CS & CC), less net book value of any property, plant, and equipment sold, adjusted at constant
currency;

- “Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)” represents Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) less vending fees for
each of Selecta, Pelican Rouge and Argenta, adjusted for scope and reconciliation, reclassification, and
constant currency adjustments. See “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”;

- “Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC)” represents our revenue on a constant scope and constant currency
basis. See “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information” for a reconciliation of revenue
to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for each period presented;

- “EBITDA” represents profit/(loss) before net finance results and income tax, before depreciation and
amortization expense;

- “gross capital expenditures” consist of self-service retail equipment purchased;

- “LTM Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)” represents our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the
twelve months ended June 30, 2019, further adjusted to give effect to estimated annualized run-rate
cost savings and synergies resulting from the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and
the Express Vending Acquisition that we have not yet realized;

- “net capital expenditures” consist of gross capital expenditures, less the book value of total disposals of
self-service retail equipment (which includes old PoS sold in such period);

- “non-IFRS cash conversion” represents the difference between Adjusted EBITDA (CC & CS) and
Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS &CC), divided by Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC);

- “revenue net of vending fee” represents our revenue less vending fee;

- “Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA” represents Adjusted EBITDA as further adjusted to give effect to the
cost savings and synergies that we have realized and expect to achieve as a result of the Pelican Rouge
Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition, as described further in
“Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Other Information—Historical Consolidated Financial
_Information—Other Financial Data and Operating Information”; and_

- “Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin” represents Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of
revenue net of vending fee.

xii


-----

These non-GAAP measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS
and should not be considered as alternatives to revenue or net profit for the period or any other performance
measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as
alternatives to cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities.

Some of the limitations of non-GAAP measures are that:

   - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual
commitments;

   - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

   - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service
interest or principal payments on our debt;

   - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

   - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to
be indicative of our ongoing operations;

   - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA-based measures do not reflect any
cash requirements that would be required for such replacements;

   - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating certain EBITDA-based measures reflect
cash payments that were made, or may be made in the future; and

   - other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their
usefulness as comparative measures.

**_Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information_**

We also present in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited non-GAAP aggregated financial
information (the “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”) on a constant scope and
constant currency basis for the relevant periods. The results of operation for each of the Pelican Rouge Group,
the Argenta Group and the Express Vending Group are represented in our Historical Financial Statements only as
of the respective date of each of their acquisition. As a result, our Historical Financial Statements are not directly
comparable with each other for each of the relevant periods. We also completed a number of disposals between
2016 and 2018, which also affect the comparability of our financial results between periods. We believe that
presenting the Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information is useful to investors in evaluating our
financial performance as we believe this information will aid comparability of our results of operations. The
Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any
generally accepted accounting standards nor with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the
Prospectus Regulation, or any other regulations of the Securities Exchange Commission, or any other regulator.
The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been derived by applying adjustments to our
Historical Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, which adjustments are not
recognized by IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards.

The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been derived by applying certain
adjustments to each of our Historical Financial Statements and the financial statements of the Pelican Rouge
Group, the Argenta Group and the Express Vending Group for the relevant periods. Such adjustments fall within
two categories, adjusting for the scope of the financial information included (constant scope adjustments) and the
exchange rates used in respect of the financial information recorded in currencies other than euro (constant
currency adjustments), as described in detail below.

_Constant Scope Adjustments_

The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to give effect to the
transactions described below, as if they had occurred on October 1, 2015, to the extent they were not already
reflected in the relevant period:

   - the acquisition by Selecta AG of the Pelican Rouge Group, which occurred on September 7, 2017, and
contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 6, 2017;

   - the acquisition by TopCo of the Argenta Group, which occurred on February 2, 2018, and contributes
to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to February 1, 2018;

   - the acquisition by Selecta AG of the Express Vending Group, which occurred on August 17, 2018, and
contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to August 16, 2018;

   - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Sweden, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes
to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016;

   - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Germany, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes
to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016;

   - the disposal of Selecta subsidiaries in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which occurred in March 2017,
and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 30, 2016;

   - the disposal of a Selecta subsidiary in Finland, which occurred in March 2018, and contributes to the
adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 30, 2017; and

   - the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which occurred on September 19, 2018, and contributes to the
adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 18, 2018.

While the Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to reflect acquisitions
that we consider significant, it does not reflect all acquisitions we have completed during the relevant period. We
categorize acquisitions of businesses with less than €3.0 million in gross sales for the twelve months preceding
such acquisition as part of our organic growth. Consequently, transactions involving such acquisitions are not
included in the constant scope adjustments to our Historical Financial Statements.

In addition to the above, adjustments are made as a result of accounting policy differences and
reclassifications, as further detailed under “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information—Adjusted
_Revenue (CS & CC) and Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)” and “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial_
_Information—Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC).”_

been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data in this Offering Memorandum may
vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes
over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in the section entitled “Management’s Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” are calculated using the numerical data in the_
Historical Financial Statements or the tabular presentation of other data (subject to rounding) contained in this
Offering Memorandum, as applicable, and do not use the numerical data in the narrative description thereof. As a
result of such rounding, the totals of certain financial information presented in tabular form may differ from the
information that would have appeared in such totals using the unrounded financial information.

**INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA**

This Offering Memorandum contains statistics, data and other information regarding markets, market sizes,
market shares, market positions, growth rates and other industry data pertaining to the Group’s business and
markets. Unless otherwise indicated, such information is based on the Issuer’s analysis of multiple sources, and
the industry and market data. Such information has been accurately reproduced and, as far as the Issuer is aware
from such information, no facts have been omitted which would render the information provided inaccurate or
misleading.

In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the market in
which we operate and compete. Certain market data and economic and industry data and forecasts used in this
Offering Memorandum were obtained from governmental and other publicly available information, independent
industry publications and reports prepared by industry consultants. These include information extracted without
material adjustment from a commissioned report published by OC&C Strategy Consultants (“OC&C”). The
OC&C Report has been produced based on publications comprising industry data, forecasts, surveys and other
information made available to OC&C by third-party data providers. Some of the data in those publications are
based on estimates in respect of our business whereas OC&C have been provided with actual data by us. The
OC&C Report is therefore based on a combination of third-party sources, adjusted where appropriate to reflect
actual data. As such, the data, statistics and analysis provided by OC&C may differ from the data, statistics and
analysis contained in other industry publications. OC&C’s views on markets and their competitive environment
are derived from a broad range of sources, and include market projections based on estimated historic growth
rates, the projection of known factors which have driven historic market growth and their projected future
evolution. There is an inherent degree of uncertainty in these projections; they are estimates and should be treated
as such. In addition, we have also included information regarding the market in which we operate, which is based
on internal data, management’s estimates, and other sources. In considering the industry and market data
included in this Offering Memorandum, prospective investors should note that such information may be subject
to significant uncertainty due to differing definitions of the relevant markets and market segments described. In
many cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations, government
bodies or other organizations) to independently verify our market related analyses and estimates, thus requiring
us to rely on internally developed data. Consequently, we have made certain estimates largely based on internal
surveys and studies. In the absence of such information, we have made statements regarding our industry and
market share based on our experience, our own investigation of market conditions and our management’s best
estimates. When discussing market share for the year ended December 31, 2017, the terms “we,” “us,” and “our”
include for such purpose the market share of Argenta, even though the Argenta Acquisition was not completed
until February 2, 2018. While we believe our estimates to be reasonable, they have not been verified by any
independent sources and we cannot assure you that any of our assumptions are accurate or correctly reflect our
position in the industry. Neither we nor any of the Managers make any representation as to the accuracy of such
information.

While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such
data involves risks and uncertainties and is subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed
under the headings “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements” in this Offering Memorandum.

adverse effect on our business;

the consumer’s experience with the vending machines we operate;

   - our business is exposed to fluctuations in costs related to fuel, coffee and other commodity prices;

   - changes in governmental regulations and legislation could adversely affect our business;

   - we operate in a highly competitive market, and if we do not compete effectively, we may lose market
share or be unable to maintain or increase prices for our products and services;

   - an increase in vending rent rates could negatively affect our business;

   - our success is dependent, in part, upon the integrity of our management and employees, and our risk
management and internal controls may not prevent or detect violations of law, including mishandling
of cash;

   - a failure of our key information technology, accounting software, and inventory management systems
or processes could have a material adverse effect on our ability to conduct our business;

   - we may not successfully implement our business strategies, including achieving our growth objectives;

   - we may incur civil and criminal liability due to infringements of the Swiss Data Protection Act and
other applicable data protection laws relating to theft, loss, or misuse of data relating to our employees,
customers or other third parties;

   - defects, failures or security breaches in and inadequate upgrades of, or changes to, our PoS and the
accompanying software could harm our business;

   - any negative impact on the reputation of the brand names of certain of the key products we sell may

on food and beverage items sold in vending machines and any further increase in VAT could require us
to incur additional costs and have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial

conducting business in multiple countries;

   - we depend on a limited number of suppliers for the manufacture of the vending machines and the
provision of telemetry equipment we require to operate our business;

**Overview**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by
revenue with more than 475,000 points of sale (“PoS”) in 16 countries as of June 30, 2019, covering
approximately 95% of European GDP and approximately 78% of the European population. We held the number
one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets of Belgium, France,
Finland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. We served over
ten million consumers per day via more than 3,800 routes as of June 30, 2019. We operate in a highly fragmented
market, which provides growth opportunities, both organically and through accretive acquisitions. For the twelve
months ended June 30, 2019, we generated a revenue of €1,580.8 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of
€267.7 million, and we would have generated an Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,604.7 million and an
Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €271.2 million, achieving 3.8% Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth
compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, and 18.9% Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margins.

The following map illustrates the countries in which we operate, our geographical segments as of June 30,
2019, and our market positions in the Focus Countries (as defined below) for the year ended December 30, 2017.

_Source: OC&C. Market data as of 2017. Our market share in Italy consists of the 2017 market share of Argenta, which we acquired in_
_February 2018. Our market share in the UK consists of the 2017 market share of Selecta combined with (i) the 2017 market share of the UK_
_operations of Pelican Rouge, which we acquired in September 2017, and (ii) the 2017 market share of Express Vending, which we acquired in_
_August 2018._

Our diversified product offering includes both coffee and hot drinks, and we have entered into strong
partnerships with global premium coffee brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza, which allow us to benefit from
consumers’ increasing preference for premium products, especially coffee, and result in higher margins. We also
cater to the impulse-based consumer purchases with offerings of snacks, including healthy options, cold drinks
and fresh food sold through traditional impulse PoS as well as our recently introduced MicroMarkets concept.


1


-----

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) as a percentage of the types of
items we sell amounted to 56% for coffee and hot drinks, 29% for impulse items, and 15% for other.

We serve customers and generate revenue in the workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business
channels further discussed below:

(*) Adjusted Revenue (CS & CS) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019.

Our business model covers the full value chain of the coffee and convenience food Unattended SSR Market,
from green bean roasting to brewing to the consumer’s cup, and we have developed industry leading coffee
know-how, capabilities, and expertise in connection with these processes. We roast and produce both instant and
full bean coffee, which we use in our own PoS, our customers’ PoS and also sell to third parties, and as such, our
roaster in Dordrecht, the Netherlands, is an important driver of our coffee expertise. We have created a strong
portfolio of high-quality coffee brands, such as our in-house developed Pelican Rouge brand and its
craftsmanship image that caters for growing number of consumers increasingly looking for this attribute. Our
Pelican Rouge brand complements our premium coffee offering in partnership with Lavazza and Starbucks. We
leverage our technology capabilities and data collection from PoS to provide relevant products, gauge consumer
preferences and maximize revenue opportunities, which improve consumer experience and customer satisfaction.
We also provide cleaning, maintenance, and technical support services which can be customized based on
individual customer needs and preferences, even when we do not enter into a full self-service retail service
arrangement with the customer. In addition to our unattended self-service and coffee roasting operations, we also
sell coffee and machines, including to hotels, restaurants and cafés, and machine parts and products independent
of self-service retail service arrangements.

Due to the predictable nature of our business and the length of our customer contracts, we believe we are
able to achieve high revenue visibility. We benefit from diversified revenue streams secured by multi-year
contracts derived from a large and loyal customer base across private and public sector in 2018 and a 100%
retention rate with our top ten customers over that period. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that our average
private customer contract term is three to five years, and our average public customer contract term is five to ten
years. Moreover, the maintenance and cleaning services we offer as part of our self-service retail services provide
us with an additional source of high margin revenues.

Innovation and technology are also key drivers of our success, and we benefit from our track record of
innovation leadership both in terms of technology upgrades such as cashless payment, touchscreen user
interfaces and telemetry, as well as in terms of unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to
drive daily revenue per PoS and open new routes-to-market.


2


-----

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown organically as well as through acquisitions. On
September 7, 2017, we completed the acquisition of the Pelican Rouge Group, which increased our presence in
nine of the 15 markets in which we operated at that time, making us the market leader by revenue in France,
Spain, the United Kingdom, and Belgium. In addition, on February 2, 2018, we completed the acquisition of the
Argenta Group, a leading unattended self-service retail operator in Italy, which became our 16[th] market. On
August 17, 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium unattended self-service retail
services, bolstering our position as the leading European provider of route-based unattended self-service coffee
and impulse and convenience food offerings, including MicroMarkets, and further consolidated our leading
position in the United Kingdom. Express Vending is at the forefront of MicroMarket design and deployment in
the UK. Express Vending’s Express HUB brand stores, with open plan refreshment areas, an extensive product
range and self-scan kiosks.

As a result of these acquisitions, our innovation and technology leadership, and through upgrades of our
business, operating systems and corporate culture, we have achieved a leading position in Europe as a routebased unattended self-service retail provider with strong know-how and capabilities in providing coffee and
impulse offerings across a range of workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business channels. We had
average market shares ranging between 10% and 15% in our core markets for the year ended December 30, 2017,
compared to approximately 6% of the European market over the same period in 2016, and we served over ten
million consumers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to approximately 6 million for the year
ended September 30, 2016. We see significant opportunities for further organic growth and accretive
acquisition-led growth in our highly fragmented markets.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

We believe that we benefit from the key competitive strengths listed below.

**_Business Proposition Offering Unmatched Convenience_**

We offer consumers a wide variety of on-the-go food products for everyday consumption and impulse
purchases, with a strong focus on coffee, at all hours of the day and every day of the year thanks to our
unattended, 24/7, fully automated, convenience retail concept. Our concept targets captive environments and is
economically viable even in low footfall locations due to our minimal operational costs compared with
traditional retail concepts. Our ability to sell products in convenient retail locations and our high level of
customer service has led to an average overall customer retention based on revenue of approximately 95.9% for
the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and approximately 92.5% and 94.4% for each of the years ended
September 30, 2017 and 2018, respectively. We believe that the quality of our service levels and our customer
relationship management contribute to customer loyalty, leading to an average relationship of approximately 15
years with our 10 largest customers. In addition, contract renewals with our existing long-term customers are
typically more profitable than entering into a contract with a new customer, due to savings on equipment and
other capital expenditures and customer acquisition costs. Our costs associated with new customers are followed
by predictable revenue streams and we usually recoup these costs within two years. We have a scalable routebased business model that we are able to apply across the 16 countries in which we operate with the same key
success factors, to drive growth in customers, daily revenue per PoS and profitability. For example, following the
Argenta Acquisition in 2018, we have replicated Argenta’s MicroMarkets operating model in other countries
such as Switzerland and the Netherlands. Our focus on out-of-home impulse consumption limits our exposure to
competition from online retailers and offerings.

**_Well Positioned to Take Advantage of Premium Coffee and Out-of-Home Consumption Growth_**

We operate in the convenience food and beverage market, estimated at €42 billion in 2017 (our
“Addressable Market”) in our focus countries of France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the
Netherlands, and the United Kingdom (the “Focus Countries”). Within the Addressable Market, we focus on the
Unattended SSR Market which has a market size of approximately €16 billion in our 16 countries of operations,
of which approximately €15 billion arises in the Focus Countries. Our Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR
of 2.1% between 2012 and 2017, reaching a total value of approximately €40.5 billion in the Focus Countries and
is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.1% reaching €47.1 billion by 2022. This trend has been driven by a positive
macro-economic backdrop with an increase in GDP and stable employment levels, which have led to increased
spending in the workplace channel. In addition, we believe that an increasing preference for drinking premium
coffee and out-of-home consumption, increased mobility, and the desire for easy availability of healthy and
quality products is driving consumers towards our pan-European on-the-go self-service retail offerings. For


3


-----

example, sales of coffee within the Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.8% between 2012 to 2017,
reaching €16.0 billion, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.9%, reaching €19.4 billion by 2022.

Moreover, the growing trend toward premium brands has created a shift in consumer emphasis on high
quality product offerings, including organic and name-brand coffee, a trend which we are addressing with our
Starbucks, and Lavazza brand partnerships. For example, we are able to offer consumers a premium hot drinks
experience, both in the workplace and on-the-go through our long-standing partnership with Starbucks. As of
June 30, 2019, we have installed approximately 1,964 Starbucks concepts across Europe, and the price of a
coffee sold in our Starbucks on-the-go concept is between 20% to 90% higher than a coffee sold in traditional
self-service PoS, and such trends for premium brands support our profitability. Similarly, through our partnership
with Lavazza we offer our customers and consumers additional options for a premium coffee experience. As of
June 30, 2019, we had over 15,637 PoS selling Lavazza coffee and we estimate that approximately 40,000 PoS
will serve Lavazza coffee in the long-term.

**_Leading Unattended Self-Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in the European Unattended SSR_**
**_Market with Growth above Market_**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in the
Unattended SSR Market, and had an estimated 10% market share by revenue in the Focus Countries for the year
ended December 30, 2017, compared to 6% over the same period in 2016. We believe that our adjusted revenue
(on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5
times that of the second largest market player. As of June 30, 2019, we had operations in 16 European countries,
which covered approximately 95% of European GDP and contain approximately 78% of the European
population. In 2016, we served over six million consumers per day, which we have nearly doubled to more than
ten million consumers served per day. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue
in 2017 in our ten core markets, and we estimate that this market data is still accurate as of the date of this
Offering Memorandum. Our sales in these markets represented 90.7% of our revenue for the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we operated a network of more than 475,000 active coffee and
convenience food and beverage self-service PoS, approximately 2.5 times the number of PoS of the second
largest market player. With regards to our suppliers, we believe we are the largest machine buyer in the highly
fragmented Unattended SSR Market, making us the customer of choice for our suppliers, which in turn provides
us with competitively priced procurement arrangements on, amongst other, a wide selection of market leading
machines.

The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We
are one of the very few operators on a pan-European level, which increases the appeal of our brands and
offerings with consumers and of our services and concepts with customers, as compared with our smaller
competitors. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in each of our three
geographic segments was split relatively evenly with Central accounting for 37%, North accounting for 26%, and
South, UK & Ireland accounting for 37%. This is in contrast to the second largest market player, over three
quarters of whose revenue in its last financial year was derived from Italy alone. In addition, the breadth of our
product portfolio enables us to better address consumers’ preferences across geographic segments, including
evolving market trends, and to provide a one-stop shop offering for our customers. Additionally, our established
brands and unique concepts differentiate us from our competitors and enable us to secure attractive and
comprehensive contracts with a variety of suppliers and premium brands, which help us maintain our high
market share.

**_Using Innovation and Technology to Drive Growth and Improve Margins_**

We use innovation and new technologies to drive our growth and improve margins, and we have a track
record of innovation leadership through continuous rollouts of upgrades to our PoS across all geographies.
Innovation and technology improve the consumer experience, enhance operational excellence and allow us to
further expand our route-based business model. Cashless payment systems and digital touchscreen user interfaces
that we are rolling out across our PoS park enhance the consumer experience by providing additional
accessibility and simplicity of use, thereby driving number of sales and average transaction size compared to
cash transactions. As of June 30, 2019, daily revenue per PoS equipped with cashless technology are on average
10% to 20% higher than PoS that only accept cash, and the average transaction value of products sold from
cashless PoS is between 5% to 10% higher, making cashless payment options an important driver in increasing
sales from existing PoS. As of June 30, 2019, 95% of our public PoS deployed cashless technology. Telemetry in
our PoS allows us to better adjust our pricing and product offerings to drive sales and to more efficiently monitor


4


-----

inventory levels and determine maintenance requirements, which increases our route efficiency and operational
excellence, and thereby improves service quality and customer retention. As of June 30, 2019, we had telemetry
devices installed in approximately 95% of our public PoS. In addition to technological innovation, we also
continue to innovate and introduce new unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to adapt to
market and consumer trends, increase sales and improve profitability, while reducing capital expenditures.

**_Route-Based Business Model with High Density on the Last Mile_**

Our route-based business model combined with our size represents a distinct competitive advantage,
particularly on the last mile of service, which allows us to service and supply PoS at an optimized cost level,
thereby improving our profitability compared to other competitors. In addition, we continuously optimize the
density of our PoS to make routes more efficient, thereby reducing driving time and increasing our ability to
service more PoS per hour and more PoS per FTE. We are, therefore, able to offer more competitive pricing at
the same profitability point or the same levels of service at a lower price, as compared to less profitable smaller
regional players, thereby creating genuine barriers to match our scale. We also use data from our PoS equipped
with telemetry and our dedicated team of approximately 150 planners (as of June 30, 2019) to continuously
optimize our over 3,800 dense and cost-effective routes. As of June 30, 2019, our 4,900 route merchandizers and
1,400 route technicians were able to service their routes using a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. The map below
illustrates the location of each of our PoS, and shows the density of our route-based networks.

**_Scale Driven Business Model Creating Attractive Economics and Enhancing Established Market Presence_**

We have developed a business model with a cost advantage through economies of scale and high density,
and we believe it will be difficult for potential competitors to replicate the scale, breadth, and efficiency of our
organization. Our scale also enables us to deliver superior customer service by leveraging our knowledge of the
industry to provide customers and consumers with a comprehensive range of products and innovative service
offerings. These attributes lead to an estimated 5% to 15% EBITDA margin (as defined by and according to
OC&C) advantage over smaller competitors.

We deploy capital expenditures in order to retain and acquire new customers and do so by acquiring new
PoS and refurbishing our existing PoS in order to enhance returns on investment. Capital expenditure for new
PoS and refurbishment of existing PoS of the Group typically achieves a ROI ranging from 100% to 250%,
depending on the country, with the highest returns in the Netherlands, the UK and Switzerland. We have
consistently achieved efficiencies stemming from PoS park rationalization (which includes margin management,
relocating PoS to more profitable locations, and decreasing the types of PoS in use) and refurbishment. In
addition to the operational advantages explained above we also believe that given our scale we retain a cost
advantage over our competitors in terms of pricing from machine suppliers and that our in-house refurbishment
and maintenance capabilities also provide us a cost advantage.


5


-----

**_Attractive Financial Profile with Organic Growth, Profitability and Cash Conversion Momentum_**

Our business has delivered consistent financial results with resilient Adjusted EBITDA margins and stable
cash flow generation, with a non-IFRS cash conversion (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) minus
Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS & CC), divided by Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)) of 46.7%, 45.9%, and
52.0% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, respectively, and 49.1% for the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019. Adjusted EBITDA minus net capital expenditures, divided by Adjusted EBITDA,
amounted to 38.2%, 42.5% and 50.8% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively, and
49.0% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta
Acquisition, and the Express Vending Acquisition, we have also benefited from significant cost synergies
including, among others, procurement savings, footprint optimization, headquarters integration, and price
harmonization and streamlining. As we continue to realize synergies, our efficiency improves and cash
conversion continues on a positive trend.

Our strong market positions in key markets, coupled with our ongoing efforts to optimize PoS density and
operational efficiencies, increased technology penetration, as well as data analytics across all markets contribute
to further enhancing our financial profile and organic growth. Excluding France and the UK, we achieved
revenue growth of 4.3% for the year ended September 30, 2018, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017,
and 5.2% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, while
achieving organic revenue growth at constant scope and constant currency (as further described under
“Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”) of 3.4% and 2.7% during the same respective
periods. Additionally, through our continued efforts to install new and upgrade existing PoS as well as optimize
our product offering, we have seen a growth of 1.4% in our daily revenue per PoS in the twelve months ended
June 30, 2019 compared to the same period in 2018.

**_Experienced Executive Management Team with Proven Execution Track Record_**

We have a long and successful track record of attracting and retaining top talent and have continued to
invest in a high quality management team in order to most effectively manage our existing operations and
execute our strategies. Our senior management team is led by our CEO, David Flochel, Chairman, David Hamill,
CFO, Gabriel Pirona, and COO, Pascal Uffer, who have more than 80 years of combined experience and
leadership track record with international companies. The senior management team has a strong focus on
functional expertise and is complemented by local management teams with regional focus. Over the past three
years, the team has successfully led the roll-out of our innovative Starbucks on-the-go concepts, the
implementation of our profitable partnership with Lavazza, as well as our MicroMarkets concept, and have
successfully progressed the roll-out of new technologies for our PoS across our geographic markets and the
integration of the Pelican Rouge and Gruppo Argenta acquisitions. We believe that the collective industry
knowledge and leadership of our senior management team will enable them to continue to grow our business and
execute our strategies.

**Our Strategies**

**_Key Pillars Driving Our Strategy_**

We intend to continue to nurture our strong reputation with our customers and consumers and to deliver
consistently superior financial results, in line with our ultimate goal of achieving a culture of excellence. This
excellence stems from a driven and successful team combined with a clear, strategic, and consistent framework,
according to which we take decisions and run our business. We have identified the following key pillars driving
our strategy, as further described below.

**_Driving Performance Through Sales Excellence_**

The first line for growing our business and improving our margins is excellence in sales, as it is through
sales that we increase our pipeline of potential new contracts, increase our new contract gains and maintain our
high level of customer retention. Sales excellence is the key driver of our organic growth, and over the last two
years we committed a substantial portion of our resources to improving our salesforce effectiveness and further
strengthening our relationship with our customers. We focus on performance-led management and increased
activity dedicated to new business sales teams and account managers. As part of this initiative, we are engaging
in training, coaching on the job and concept selling to enhance the capabilities of our sales force and to lead the

**_Further Developing Pricing and Category Management_**

We believe that there is a significant opportunity to increase daily revenue per PoS by improving pricing
and category management. We have initiated an analytical approach to support decision making and assess the
impact of pricing and category management across our footprint. With telemetry now equipped on most of our
public PoS, it allows us to analyze sales data and unlock pricing capabilities in ways previously unavailable to us.
We believe this gives us an opportunity to continuously optimize performance, with location specific product
assortment and pricing initiatives, allowing us to better manage margins on underperforming accounts, upsell our
services to B2B customers, and reduce leakage to competing local offerings. We expect pricing and category
management efforts to have a more than €10.0 million impact on revenue for our 2019 fiscal year.

**_Improving Operational Excellence_**

Our route-based business model benefits from the significant increases in productivity resulting from our
dense network of PoS and depots, and we are continuously optimizing route density through professional route
planning. We thereby leverage our focus on technology and innovation to further improve our operational
excellence. For example, the installation of telemetry capabilities in our PoS allows for dynamic route planning
and increased efficiency of our refillers by reducing preparation time and enabling the refiller to visit more PoS.
Density optimization is also a key consideration in our bolt-on acquisition program, and one of the key drivers of
synergy achievement.

Our operational excellence is also driven by our success in acquiring and integrating companies, such as
Pelican Rouge, Argenta and Express Vending. Led by an integration office reporting to the Board of Directors of
the Group, we have identified approximately €75 million in annualized procurement, SG&A and operational
synergies that are at being implemented and that we expect to be fully realized by the end of 2020, resulting in a
strong margin uplift. In terms of procurement, we expect to achieve up to €30 million of annualized synergies
from equipment, ingredients, bought-in goods, disposables, packaging and spares and the in-sourcing of coffee
production. SG&A synergies in an amount of up to €13 million include the consolidation of country and group
headquarters and the optimization of overhead and corporate costs. We expect to achieve up to €33 million of
operational synergies from the transfer of best practices within our group and from an increase in density as a
result of depot, merchandizer and technician network optimization and increase in utilization of telemetry
capabilities, which drives route efficiency for our refillers.

**_Continued Roll Out and Focus on Our Technology and Innovation Capabilities_**

We deem technology and innovation to be a competitive differentiator for our current operations and
business going forward. We continue to commit resources and make the necessary investments to be at the
forefront of technology and innovation in our industry. Currently, we are managing three footprint-wide key
enablers that contribute to an improvement in daily revenue per PoS and operational efficiency. Firstly, we are
expanding and upgrading our current PoS base with telemetry technology, a remote PoS monitoring allowing for
optimization of cost-to-serve and product availability while leading the transformation toward an end-to-end
operating model. Approximately 29% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019,
while we aim to roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. Secondly, we are also upgrading our
PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point of sale by providing access to
non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park
has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. Thirdly, our MicroMarket concept allows us to introduce an
innovative, unique, and attractive format bringing together technology, brands, and operational capabilities while


7


-----

combining the classic vending model (convenience) with the cafeteria model (premium and healthy). While the
concept is already established in the UK, Italy, Switzerland and, recently, the Netherlands, we plan to roll-out the
format across our other markets to further expand our current footprint of 104 MicroMarkets as of June 30, 2019.
For example, we have launched our MicroMarket concept in Spain, where we have already entered into
agreements to install MicroMarkets, and in Germany, where we have started discussions with potential
customers.

**_Pursuing Growth Through a Disciplined Capital Expenditure Program_**

We intend to continue to pursue growth through a disciplined capital expenditure program that provides an
attractive return on investment period, while also optimizing the capital intensity of our operations. We have a
structured and consistent governance with respect to capital expenditures across our group, with pre-investments
business cases and post-investment appraisals and tracking of outcomes. At the same time, we are working to
optimize the capital intensity of our operations by refurbishing existing PoS to increase their life and maximizing
our refurbishment capabilities and re-siting underperforming PoS. We also intend to continue exploring
off-balance sheet funding options, such as our alternative arrangements with Lavazza and other leasing
companies, to finance PoS investments for our customers, thereby reducing our initial investment cost for new
client contracts. Innovative route-based solutions such as MicroMarkets also have lower capital expenditure
requirements than classic impulse purchase offerings, while generating two to three times the revenue of a classic
self-service retail site, with each MicroMarket generating an approximate turnover of €50,000 annually. Through
these and other initiatives, we intend to reduce our PoS related cash capital expenditures to under €100.0 million
per year.

continue our growth, improve our density and improve our technical as well as service capabilities. The
Unattended SSR Market is characterized by a large number of operators, which on average tend to be very small
in terms of revenue. The following table shows the competitor fragmentation in certain of our key markets:

This fragmentation, and our position as the leader in the Unattended SSR Market, provide us with a large
number of bolt-on acquisition opportunities. We have completed five bolt-on acquisitions over the past two
years. Each acquisition we make is underpinned by a clear strategy, whether it be to increase density in existing
regions, develop market shares, expand our portfolio of offerings, improve technical capabilities in specialized
services or some combination of the foregoing. We aim to purchase companies at mid-single-digit EV/EBITDA
multiples, and to extract at least a turn of synergies from those acquisitions. Underpinning our success in bolt-on


8


-----

acquisitions is a disciplined execution and integration program that has been proven through our track record of
identifying, purchasing at attractive multiples and successfully integrating these bolt-on acquisition opportunities.

**_Developing Our People_**

Our people underlie our success, and we believe that our employees are an integral part in successfully
executing our strategies. To that end, we are undertaking initiatives related to performance management, sales
and operational capabilities, employee engagement and employer branding to ensure we maximize the potential
of our talent across our organization. Included among these initiatives are talent reviews of all teams to provide
improved management of the talent pools within each of our markets. We have developed a sales and operations
academy in order to train and develop our team with the right programs to drive customer satisfaction and
efficiencies. We have also worked to improve our employee on-boarding and performance management for our
field force, with a focus on developing first-line manager capabilities. In terms of employee engagement, we
have created a baseline employee survey in partnership with GALLUP, and plan to implement a tailored action
plan based on the survey results for each team. We are also focused on improving our internal communication
strategy, with improvement of our intranet, implementation of a new ethics program and the publishing of our
first CSR report. We believe that continued implementation of these initiatives, and a focus on the continued
development of our people, will support the execution of our strategies.

**The Issuer**

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid)
incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands. The Issuer is registered with the trade register of the Dutch
Chambers of Commerce (Handelsregister van de Kamer van Koophandel) under the number 34256233. The
Issuer’s registered business address is Overschiestraat 61-5, 1062 XD Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

**Our History**

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown both organically as well as through acquisitions.
Following our first acquisition in Switzerland in 1959, we expanded into Germany in 1986, Sweden and France
in 1990, Austria, Slovakia and the Baltic countries in 1995, Belgium in 1997, Spain in 1998, the United Kingdom
and Ireland in 2001 and the Netherlands in 2004. In 1985, we were acquired by the Valora group, and, in 1997,
we listed on the SIX before de-listing in 2001. In 2001, we were acquired by the Compass group before
becoming part of Allianz Capital Partners through its acquisition of our business in 2007. We were acquired by
KKR in 2015.

In September 2017, we acquired the Pelican Rouge Group, previously known as Autobar Group Ltd, a
company incorporated in London in 1925, which engages in roasting and blending, packaging, and self-service
retail of coffee in the United Kingdom and internationally. In 2014, Autobar Group changed its name to Pelican
Rouge and relocated to Dordrecht, the Netherlands. The coffee brand Pelican Rouge (Roode Pelikaan) was
originally founded in 1863 in Antwerp.

In February 2018, we acquired the Argenta Group. Since its founding in Carpi, Modena, Italy in 1968, the
Argenta Group has grown organically as well as through acquisitions to become the second largest food and
beverage self-service retail operator in the Italian market. In 2016, the Argenta Group expanded into southern
Italy through the acquisition of Somed, and into the food retail business under the Foodie’s brand and through
agreements with 365 Retail Market with its MicroMarket concept.

In August 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium self-service retail
services with a focus on London and its neighboring counties. Express Vending’s offering of products and
services includes table top coffee machines and MicroMarkets. Express Vending was established in 1992 and is
headquartered in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, Great Britain. We also made three smaller acquisitions in
Italy in 2018.

**About KKR**

KKR is a leading global investment firm with a long history of investing in Europe. Founded in 1976 and
led by Henry Kravis and George Roberts, KKR had $205.7 billion in assets under management as of June 30,
2019. With offices around the world, KKR manages assets through a variety of investment funds and accounts
covering multiple asset classes. KKR seeks to create value by bringing operational expertise to its portfolio


9


-----

companies and through active oversight and monitoring of its investments. KKR complements its investment
expertise and strengthens interactions with investors through its client relationships and capital markets
platforms.
