**Overview**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by
revenue with more than 475,000 PoS in 16 countries as of June 30, 2019, covering approximately 95% of
European GDP and approximately 78% of the European population. We held the number one or number two
market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets of Belgium, France, Finland, Italy, the
Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. We served over ten million
consumers per day via more than 3,800 routes as of June 30, 2019. We operate in a highly fragmented market,
which provides growth opportunities, both organically and through accretive acquisitions. For the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019, we generated a revenue of €1,580.8 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €267.7 million,
and we would have generated an Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,604.7 million and an Adjusted EBITDA
(CS & CC) of €271.2 million, achieving 3.8% Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth compared to the twelve
months ended June 30, 2018, and 18.9% Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margins.

**Our Segments and Business Channels**

**_Geographic Segments_**

We report our revenue and certain other financial data by geographic segment. The geographic segments in
which we operate correspond to our reporting segments under IFRS and consist of the following for the year
ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019:

   - _South, UK & Ireland includes operating entities in Ireland, Italy, Spain and the UK;_

   - _Central includes operating entities in Austria, France, Germany, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland; and_

   - _North includes operating entities in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands,_
Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2017, one operating entity in Finland was classified as held for
sale and excluded from this segment; it was subsequently sold in March 2018.

In addition to the segments identified above, we report separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which includes
corporate center functions in Switzerland and certain functions of former Pelican Rouge entities in the
Netherlands and in the UK.

For comparative purposes, we also presented our revenue and certain other financial data for the year ended
September 30, 2017, in line with the above geographic segments in our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements.

For the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, we reported our revenue by the following geographic
segments:

   - _France included operating entities in France;_

   - _West included operating entities in Belgium, Ireland, the Netherlands and the UK;_

65


-----

   - _Central included operating entities in Austria, Germany, Spain, and Switzerland; and_

   - _North included operating entities in Denmark, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, and_
Sweden. As of October 1, 2016, operating entities in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania were classified as
held for sale and excluded from this segment; they were subsequently sold in March 2017.

In addition to the segments identified above, we reported separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which
included corporate center functions in Switzerland.

**_Business Channels_**

We also report our revenue and certain other financial data by business channel. Our business channels
consist of the following for the year ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and
2019:

   - The workplace channel, which includes revenue from (i) private self-service retail, consisting of PoS
placed and serviced in various private locations, such as large corporate customers, in various
businesses and industries and including in corporate offices, manufacturing and logistics sites, and
(ii) OCS, which is comprised of table-top coffee machines rented out to corporate customers (mainly
small and medium-sized enterprises) for office use along with the provision of technical services and
coffee and related supplies for the PoS;

   - The on-the-go channel, which includes revenue from PoS placed and serviced in semi-public areas,
such as hospitals, universities and entertainment venues, or public areas, such as train stations, airports
and gas stations, following a successful bidding process with relevant government authorities to place
our PoS in a given location; and

   - The trading channel, which includes revenue from sales of machines and products, including coffee
roasted in our roasting facility and the provision of technical and hygienic support to customers.

We did not report our revenue by the above business channels in our financial statements for prior periods,
including for the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017. However, for comparative purposes, we presented
our revenue for the year ended September 30, 2017, by business channels in our 2018 Consolidated Financial
Statements.

**Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition**

Our results of operation are affected by a combination of factors, including factors which are beyond our
control. We believe that our results of operations, and particularly the results of operation during the periods
under review, have been primarily affected by the following factors.

**_General Economic Conditions, Consumer Spending and Consumer Preferences_**

Demand for our PoS and products is affected by general economic conditions and consumer spending.
Changes in general economic conditions directly impact consumer spending as well as the investment levels of
our customers in non-essential services, such as PoS and services. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019,
we derived 47.0% of our revenue from workplace points of sale, which include OCS. As PoS in such privately
placed points of sale are generally located on companies’ premises in office environments and similar locations,
macroeconomic factors such as GDP and employment levels, among others, affect the number of items sold
through these PoS. For example, reductions in workforce numbers or hours worked during times of economic
downturn (including the effects of reduced overtime, layoffs and increased reliance on part-time versus full-time
workers) means that our PoS on companies’ premises and in office environments are available to fewer
consumers or consumers with lower purchasing power due to reduced income or more conservative spending
habits. On the other hand, economic growth may have a positive impact on our ability to generate new business if
companies invest in non-essential services, such as the decision to contract for the placement of a PoS on their
premises. Variations in consumer spending or consumer purchasing power can also affect revenue generated
from our PoS in public locations, but macroeconomic conditions generally have less impact on our public selfservice retail operations compared to our private operations.

In addition, our revenues in any given period are affected by our ability to maintain the appeal of our PoS to
existing consumers and attract new consumers, which depends on continuous development and improvement of
our range of products and services offering that are responsive to evolving trends and consumer preferences. For
instance, our increasing focus on premium coffee brands and the introduction of touchscreen technology and

66


-----

cashless payment options for our PoS, including our mobile phone app, Selecta eWallet, are driven by changing
consumer behaviors. Specific factors affecting consumer spending in our PoS include our ability to maintain and
improve an attractive product assortment, including through partnerships with Starbucks and Lavazza, the
location and overall aesthetic appeal of our PoS, the accessibility and integration of our on-the-go PoS channels,
and our ability to effectively predict and respond to quickly changing consumer demands and preferences.

**_Seasonality and Weather_**

Our vends of certain products have historically been affected by seasonal variation during the year. Many of
our PoS include cold drinks, which have historically generated increased sales during the summer months. Coffee
sales generally exhibit less variation, but may also be affected by seasonal factors, especially for our PoS inside
offices or in other private locations, where sales are lower during holiday seasons. In addition, severe weather
can influence consumer traffic patterns in high-traffic areas such as gas stations, train and subway stations, and
airports. If, for example, transportation services are closed due to heavy snow or rain, our PoS in such locations
may be accessible by significantly fewer consumers and vends lost on a particular business day typically cannot
be recouped in the future.

**_Capital Expenditures_**

We incur capital expenditures in connection with the purchase of new PoS and the refurbishment of existing
PoS in the ordinary course of business. We own approximately 78% of the PoS that we service, which we fund
through cash on balance sheet or finance leases, with the remaining PoS being owned or leased directly by our
customers. In addition, we incur capital expenditures in connection with the development of new technologies for
the retail industry, such as the ability to transmit sales and stock data remotely. We divide our capital
expenditures into gross capital expenditures, net capital expenditures, and cash capital expenditures. Gross
capital expenditures consist of self-service retail equipment purchased; net capital expenditures consist of gross
capital expenditures less the book value of total disposals of self-service retail equipment (which includes old
PoS sold); and cash capital expenditures consist of net capital expenditures net of self-service retail equipment
bought through finance lease arrangements during the same period. Capital expenditures excludes purchase of
PoS where alternative arrangements are made through third parties, such as Lavazza, to finance PoS investments.

We have launched a capital intensity program in order to reduce our total cash capital expenditure. A part of
our capital intensity program is to focus on refurbishing our PoS rather than purchasing new PoS, with a view of
expanding the life cycle of our PoS from 6 to 18 years, which in turn decreases the number of new PoS required
to maintain our PoS park. As part of this capital intensity program, we have also established two PoS upgrade
centers in Madrid and Milan.

**_Customers_**

We believe that we have stable relationships with our customers, many of whom are longstanding
customers. For example, the average length of our top ten customer contracts is over 15 years. In addition, our
customer base is highly fragmented, which limits our dependence on any single customer. For the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019, our top ten customers accounted for 9.0% of our revenue and our largest customer by
revenue accounted for 1.5% of our revenue. Nevertheless, the gain or loss of significant customers or a large
number of customers in the same period would affect our results of operations.

We manage our customer relationships differently depending on the market segment. With our workplace
customers, our contractual relationships have a shorter duration, typically between three and five years, but such
contracts often renew automatically. Customers in our on-the-go business channel (like train stations, gas
stations, public institutions and hospitals) will typically organize periodic tenders for the assignment of multiyear contracts, sometimes lasting five to over ten years. Larger customers will also generally charge us a vending
fee to place our PoS on their premises. Vending fees are negotiated according to formulas related to past or
expected traffic in the relevant location and number of vends; vending fees can be either variable (based on total
sales from the applicable PoS) or fixed (based on the number of PoS installed pursuant to the relevant contract).
Our considerable experience in the self-service retail industry provides us with extensive datasets that we can use
to calculate acceptable vending fees that will allow us to submit competitive bids on commercially viable pricing
terms.

**_PoS Density, Concept and Product Mix_**

Our results of operations and profit before interest and income tax are affected by a combination of factors,
including the number of PoS in a given area, the type of PoS, the product mix in our PoS and the level of services

67


-----

we provide. In both workplace and on-the-go channels, PoS density is one of the primary drivers of profitability
and a key strategy in our acquisition program. PoS that are closer together can be more quickly and efficiently
managed by the same personnel, which reduces transport time and the relative costs associated with labor,
restocking, fuel, and maintenance. In contrast, single PoS in isolated locations may not generate sufficient gross
profit to cover the costs of visits to clean, restock, or perform scheduled or unscheduled maintenance.

Our revenue and margins are also driven by our mix of workplace and on-the-go services. Because the
margins on our products may vary, changes in the mix of our product sales have a direct impact on our total
revenue and profitability. Workplace self-service retail is our largest self-service concept by revenue and is
primarily driven by sales of coffee and other hot beverages. Workplace self-service retail margins vary based on
the type of PoS located in a particular area as well as the extent to which a customer agrees to subsidize the cost
of products for its employees, or alternatively wants to receive a vending fee on it. Consumers generally consume
more products and beverages when the cost is subsidized by their employers, leading to larger volumes of vends
and higher margins. On-the-go self-service retail margins vary primarily based on the combination of the volume
of vends and the price points for the products sold, which depend on the locations of the PoS and the number of
other locations in close proximity to our PoS that sell the same or similar products, as well as the level of vending
fee paid to the customer. Our partnerships with premium coffee brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza also
provide us with the platform to offer a compelling product mix. Therefore, the combination of location, PoS
density, product mix, prices and contributions paid to the customer are among the key factors which determine
profitability of our PoS.

**_Prices of Self-service Retail Stock and Procurement Initiatives_**

Prices of certain commodities, such as green bean coffee, cocoa and sugar, affect our cost of materials. For
example, for our own coffee brands, we estimate we require approximately 7,400 tons of arabica green bean
coffee and approximately 4,100 tons of robusta green bean coffee annually to regularly stock our hot drinks selfservice PoS or supply our customers with coffee beans. Overall, we purchase more than 20,000 tons of green
bean coffee annually for our Pelican Rouge and Miofino brands, half of which we sell to third parties. Prices for
green bean coffee have fluctuated significantly in recent years. For example, the price of arabica green bean
coffee increased considerably from November 2013 to April 2014 and, alternatively, prices ranged from
U.S.$2.30 per pound in October 2011 to U.S.$1.09 per pound in October 2018 (based on the ICE ‘C’ New York
index). In order to manage risks from fluctuations in commodities prices, we secure the green bean requirements
for periods of up to twelve months by instructing the relevant supplier to source the required green beans to cover
certain production lots at a specific price. With certain strategic suppliers, we enter into longer-term agreements
with agreed price adjustment mechanisms that reflect developments in commodity prices. For our other
ingredients such as milk powders, cocoa, and sugar, we have quarterly price contracts with our suppliers ranging
between six to twelve months.

Following the completion of the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge and Argenta, we have strengthened our
corporate procurement department to leverage our scale and obtain better prices. We have started to harmonize
prices of products we purchase for our PoS (such as snacks or cold drinks), which are traditionally sourced at the
country level, by leveraging our scale and negotiating prices with large suppliers (such as Coca-Cola) through
strategic relationships at the Group level. While certain products, such as confectionary items and other stock
items that cater to local or regional tastes, continue to be sourced on a country level, we source our own brand
green bean coffee as well as cups, sugar, and stirrers, among other supplies, through our corporate procurement
department, which allows us to secure more competitive pricing based on larger volume orders.

**_Operations and Maintenance of Our Roasting Facility_**

We operate a roasting facility in Dordrecht, Netherlands, with an annual capacity of approximately 27,000
metric tons from which we supply the Group and third parties with coffee. For the twelve months ended June 30,
2019, our roasting operations accounted for 4% of our revenue. We sell coffee to businesses, such as restaurants,
coffee shops and self-service retail operators, and, in limited quantities, directly to consumers. Our roasting
operations have primarily focused on the roasting, blending, packaging and sale of our own coffee brands,
Pelican Rouge and Miofino. The results of our roasting operations are primarily affected by the level of
marketing and pricing competition from existing or new competitors in the coffee industry, our ability to retain
existing customers and attract new customers for our coffee and fluctuations in the selling prices of Pelican
Rouge-branded coffee. In addition, investments required to maintain or repair our roasting facility have a
material impact on our capital expenditures.

68


-----

**_Anticipated Cost Savings and Synergies Resulting from Acquisitions_**

To evaluate cost savings and synergies that we have realized and expect to achieve as a result of the Pelican
Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition we have worked with consultants and advisors, including
experienced industry professionals, to examine the profile of our combined businesses and operations. The
synergies resulting from these acquisitions primarily fall into three categories: (i) logistics and footprint
optimizations, (ii) consolidation of procurement, and (iii) selling, general, and administrative costs across the
entire organization. The integration process requires changes to our purchasing practices to improve margins,
while also implementing our own systems and best practices and adjusting our combined organizational structure
and management footprint to maximize synergies. In order to supervise this integration process, we have created
an integration office at the group level led by a dedicated project manager with extensive experience in
integrations and operational turnaround reporting to the Executive Chairman of the Group and supported by our
senior management team and dedicated specialists. We expect to realize approximately €75 million of estimated
annualized run-rate cost synergies from the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition by the end of
2020. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have realized approximately €52 million
of these cost synergies, which represents 69% of our total expected cost synergies. See “Summary—Summary
_Historical Financial and Other Information—Historical Consolidated Financial Information—Other Financial_
_Data and Operating Information” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to_
_realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the_
_Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition).” See also “Forward-_
_Looking Statements.”_

Our total estimated cost synergies described above include the following:

   - Operating cost savings relating to logistics and footprint optimizations of approximately €33 million, of
which we had realized €18 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by
(i) combining operations in areas with fewer PoS to reduce the number of employees required to
maintain and refill these PoS, (ii) implementing Selecta’s refiller planning program, which is based on
actual sales of each PoS rather than a theoretical model, (iii) cost savings by leveraging data from
telemetry technology already in place in the Argenta Group’s PoS and by increasing the use of
telemetry for PoS in France, Spain and the UK (iv) headcount reductions following the assessment of
productivity of our technicians and through the integration of corporate, IT and other central functions,
(v) footprint optimization by concentrating warehouses in the countries where both Selecta and Pelican
Rouge operate, and (vi) logistics network synergies, including planning denser and more cost-effective
routes.

   - Procurement savings of approximately €30 million, of which we had realized €22 million as of
June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by (i) obtaining better prices on ingredients
through in-sourcing of our own brand coffee from Pelican Rouge’s roaster facility and international
tender of raw materials used across the countries in which we operate, such as sugar, (ii) harmonizing
prices of products we purchase for our PoS (such as snacks or cold drinks) by leveraging our scale and
negotiating prices through strategic relationships at the Group level, (iii) savings on disposables, such
as cups for our PoS, and packaging through leveraging our increased purchasing volume at the Group
level, (iv) streamlining purchases of spare parts for our PoS, (v) indirect cost savings on our fleet, IT,
marketing, and warehouses, and (vi) real estate savings as a result of terminating redundant leases and
renegotiating existing leases.

   - Selling, general, and administrative cost savings of approximately €13 million, of which we had
realized €12 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized through
(i) headcount reductions as a result of integrating management teams in countries where both Selecta
and Pelican Rouge operate and re-sizing our sales force, (ii) savings in connection with headcount
reductions in the research and development department of the Group by leveraging Argenta’s research
and development expertise, (iii) reductions in employee benefit expenses, such as cars, travel, and
mobile phones, in connection with headcount reductions, (iv) combining headquarters in countries
where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate and (v) additional productivity gains in sales, general
and administrative costs.

As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have incurred approximately €25 million in costs and capital
expenditures to implement the foregoing synergies, and estimate that we will incur approximately €28 million in
further costs and capital expenditures to realize our total targeted cost synergies. In particular, we expect to incur
(i) total estimated severance costs of approximately €24 million, of which approximately €10 million have

69


-----

already been incurred as of June 30, 2019, and (ii) estimated integration costs of approximately €29 million, of
which approximately €14 million have already been incurred as of June 30, 2019.

Although it is our objective to reach the levels of projected synergies reflected above, no assurance can be
given that such levels will be achieved in the timeframe indicated or at all or that additional unanticipated costs
will not arise. We currently estimate the majority of the cost to achieve the anticipated synergies to be personnel
reductions and related costs that may be required under the laws of the various countries where we operate,
which we expect to continue incurring over the course of the next one to two years. As part of our reorganization
plan, we are required to negotiate severance payments with worker representatives (labor unions) for FTEs being
made redundant pursuant to a collective dismissal procedure provided under applicable regulations in various of
the countries where we operate. While we fully intend to observe the relevant legal procedures and requirements
and to negotiate in good faith, if we cannot reach an agreement on severance payments with such worker
representatives or the employees, they may choose to bring administrative or judicial challenges, which could
delay the achievement of our synergies and/or increase costs incurred in order to achieve such synergies.

Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available
to us and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently
uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could
cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates, including those
described in “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to realize the anticipated
_operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge_
_Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition).” See also “Forward-Looking_
_Statements.”_

**Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements**

**_Acquisitions and Disposals_**

The comparability of our results of operations is affected by acquisitions and disposals. On August 17, 2018,
we completed the Express Vending Acquisition; on February 2, 2018, we completed the Argenta Acquisition;
and on September 7, 2017, we completed the Pelican Rouge Acquisition. We have included the operations of
each of these entities in our audited consolidated financial information as of each of their respective acquisition
dates. As a result, our audited consolidated financial information as of and for the year ended September 30,
2018, includes the operations of Express Vending from August 17, 2018 to September 30, 2018, the operations of
the Argenta Group from February 2, 2018 to September 30, 2018, and the full year results of operations of the
Pelican Rouge Group. Since our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018 do not
include the full year results of operations of the Express Vending Group and the Argenta Group, the
comparability of our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018 and as of and for the
nine months ended June 30, 2019, with our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2017,
and as of and for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, respectively, is significantly limited.

In addition, in connection with the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, in March 2018 we disposed of our Selecta
operations in Finland (“legacy Selecta Finland”) to comply with antitrust requirements. For the year ended
September 30, 2017, legacy Selecta Finland generated €13.9 million in revenue. As a result of applying IFRS 5
to our financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2017, the assets and liabilities relating to legacy
Selecta Finland are presented separately in dedicated lines in our consolidated balance sheet as of September 30,
2017. The assets presented separately as “assets classified as held for sale” in our consolidated balance sheet as
of September 30, 2017, are valued at the lower of their carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell. The
corresponding liabilities are presented separately as “liabilities associated with assets held for sale” in the
consolidated balance sheet as of September 30, 2017.

On September 19, 2018, we sold Custompack to PortionPack Europe Group. Custompack focuses on the
provision of single portion items such as wet sauces, dry products, and portion packing to its customers. Given
Selecta’s strategy around strengthening its leading position as unattended self-service convenience food and
beverage operator in Europe, Custompack was divested as a non-core business. The net disposal accounting gain
recorded on the sale amounted to €0.6 million.

We also disposed of our operations in the Baltic countries (Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia) in March 2017.

**_Categorization of Reporting Segments and Business Channels_**

_Geographic Segments_

Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition, we have recategorized our
geographic areas and the countries in each area for our financial statements. As a result, our audited consolidated
financial information as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018, includes financial data for three new
geographic segments (South, UK & Ireland, Central, and North), which significantly differ from our previous
four geographic areas (France, West, Central, and North). See “—Our Segments and Business Channels—
_Geographic Segments.” For comparative purposes, our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements include our_
results according to the three new geographic segments for the year ended September 30, 2017. Therefore, the
comparability of our results of operations by geographic segments as of and for the years ended September 30,
2017 and 2018, with our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2016, is significantly
limited.

_Business Channels_

Beginning October 1, 2017, we categorized our revenue by business channels for our financial statements.
As a result, our subsequent financial statements include our revenue by workplace, on-the-go, and trading
channels. For comparative purposes, our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements include our results according to
such categorization for the year ended September 30, 2017. This categorization did not exist for our financial
statements for previous years and therefore our revenue by business channel for the years ended September 30,
2017 and 2018, cannot be compared with information in our financial statements for the year ended
September 30, 2016. See “—Our Segments and Business Channels—Business Channels.”

**_Changes in Accounting Policy_**

IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 and became effective on January 1, 2019. As our
financial year begins on October 1[st] each year, we will apply IFRS 16 to our financial statements beginning from
October 1, 2019. IFRS 16 introduces a single accounting model for lessees that principally obligates lessees to
account for right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for lease contracts with a term of more than twelve months.
The significant impact of IFRS 16 is the elimination of the classification according to IAS 17 (Leases) of lease
contracts as operating leases and finance leases. As a result, leases, which were shown off-balance sheet
according to IAS 17, will be recognized as a right-of-use asset and lease liability on the balance sheet as of
October 1, 2019. We intend to apply the modified retrospective approach to adopt IFRS 16, and will not restate
comparative amounts for the year prior to first adoption. IFRS 16 will primarily affect the accounting for our
operating leases. We currently expect that IFRS 16 will lead to an increase in total assets and total liabilities of
approximately €150 million from the effect of recognizing existing operating leases on the balance sheet.
Additionally, annual operating lease expenses of approximately €40 million are expected to be presented as
depreciation and interest expenses in the future, with a reduction for a similar amount in rent expenses, as part of
our operating expenses. As a result of the implementation of IFRS 16, the comparability of our results presented
in our future financial statements will be significantly limited compared to our Historical Financial Statements.

**Description of Key Income Statement Items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue means our gross revenue from our publicly accessible PoS, our privately placed PoS and from
trade sales of machines and products, including sale of our private coffee brands, Pelican Rouge and Miofino, to
businesses, such as restaurants, coffee shops and self-service retail operators and in limited quantities directly to
consumers. It also includes revenue from the rendering of technical services and rental income from PoS placed
at customer sites under a rental contract and rental of advertising space.

Revenue from the sale of goods is recognized when the goods are delivered to the customer’s site or when
goods are purchased from a PoS by a consumer, depending on the contract terms. Revenue may be received
directly in the form of cash from the consumer, or may be invoiced to a customer periodically. Where revenue is
received in the form of cash, the amount recognized is the amount of cash received until the last date on which
the cash was collected from the PoS, plus an estimate of the sales between this date and the period end. This
estimate is calculated based on historical trends of sales from PoS in similar areas. Where the sale of goods is
invoiced to the customer, the amount recognized is based either on the amounts delivered to the customer or on
the consumption in the PoS, depending on the specific contractual terms.

71


-----

**_Vending Fee_**

Vending fee relates to the consideration Selecta pays to its customers for the use of the location on the
customer’s premises to install, operate, supply, and maintain PoS.

**_Materials and Consumables Used_**

Materials and consumables used primarily relates to our cost of materials (which mainly consists of
ingredients and products used to fill our PoS or for trade sales, spare parts used in servicing our PoS and the cost
of machines sold as trade business) adjusted for rebates and discounts.

**_Employee Benefits Expense_**

Employee benefits expense consists of wages and salaries as well as social security costs and postemployment benefits under defined contributions and benefit plans.

**_Depreciation, Amortization, and Impairment Expense_**

Depreciation, amortization, and impairments relate to depreciation of property, plant and equipment, which
we initially recognize at cost and depreciate using a straight-line method over their estimated useful lives, and
amortization and impairment of tangible and intangible assets.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**

Other operating expenses primarily consist of maintenance, administration expense and travel and
representation expenses and non-vending fee expenses.

**_Finance Costs and Finance Income_**

Net finance costs consist of finance costs, net of finance income. Financial costs consist of interest on bank
loans, finance lease expense and other interest expense as well as changes in the fair value of derivative financial
instruments and net foreign exchanges gains or losses. Finance income consists of gains generated on foreign
exchange transactions, interest on cash deposits and fair value gains on derivative financial instruments.

**_Income Taxes_**

Income taxes represent income and expenses in respect of current and deferred income taxes.

_Revenue_

Revenue increased by €129.3 million, or 11.9%, from €1,084.4 million for the nine months ended June 30,
2018, to €1,213.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the
acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €111.3 million to our revenue for
the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset
by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which had a negative impact of €13.2 million on our revenue over the same
period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals, our revenue for the nine months ended June 30, 2019,
would have increased by €31.3 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to an
increase of €19.6 million in revenue from our public business channel in Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands
and in the Central region, and an increase of €16.1 million in trade machine sales, primarily in the North region.
This increase was partly offset by our results of operations in France and the United Kingdom where we are
currently implementing our turnaround plans.

_Vending Fee_

Vending fee increased by €17.4 million, or 16.0%, from €108.6 million for the nine months ended June 30,
2018, to €126.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the
acquisition of Argenta, which contributed €7.3 million to our vending fee expenses for the nine months June 30,
2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. The acquisition of Express Vending and the disposal of
Custompack Ltd. did not impact our vending fees as they had no on-the-go business during these periods.
Without giving effect to the acquisition of Argenta, our vending fees for the nine months June 30, 2019, would
have increased by €10.2 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to the increase
in revenue in our public segment, which has associated vending fees.

_Materials and Consumables Used_

Expenses for materials and consumables used increased by €31.2 million, or 8.4%, from €372.2 million for
the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €403.4 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase
was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed
€34.9 million to materials and consumables used for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months
ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which reduced

73


-----

materials and consumables used by €10.3 million over the same period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and
disposals, material and consumable expenses for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by
€6.5 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to the increase in revenue across
the Group.

_Employee Benefits Expense_

Employee benefits expense increased by €32.7 million, or 10.2%, from €322.0 million for the nine months
ended June 30, 2018, to €354.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due
to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €34.0 million to employee
benefit expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This
increase was partly offset by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which reduced employee benefit expenses by
€3.1 million over the same period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals, our employee benefit
expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, would have increased by €1.8 million compared to the nine months
ended June 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to growth projects in certain countries, such as
Switzerland, and expenses incurred in connection with investments in capabilities related to strategic
transactions, which were largely offset by cost savings in connection with our synergy program and rightsizing
our operations in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, and Spain.

_Depreciation and Amortization Expense_

Depreciation and amortization expense increased by €16.7 million, or 12.6%, from €132.4 million for the
nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €149.1 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was
primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €8.3 million to
our depreciation and amortization expense, mainly through depreciation expenses, for the nine months June 30,
2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over
the period, our depreciation and amortization expense for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have
increased by €8.4 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to amortization of
customer contracts at a Group level.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Other operating expenses increased by €23.8 million, or 14.3%, from €166.9 million for the nine months
ended June 30, 2018, to €190.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due
to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €13.7 million to other
operating expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018.
Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our other operating expenses for the nine
months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €10.1 million compared to the nine months ended
June 30, 2018, primarily due to operating expenses, such as consulting expenses of €7.2 million incurred at our
headquarters and mainly related to strategic transactions.

_Net Finance Costs_

Net finance costs decreased by €40.7 million, or 37.2%, from €109.5 million for the nine months ended
June 30, 2018, to €68.8 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. The acquisitions of Argenta and
Express Vending contributed €10.5 million of net finance costs for the nine months June 30, 2019. Without
giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our net financing costs for the nine months June 30,
2019, would have decreased by €51.2 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to
foreign exchange gains on intercompany investments that are not eliminated upon consolidation of intra-group
balances.

_Income Taxes_

Income taxes decreased by €5.6 million, or 76.7%, from €7.3 million for the nine months ended June 30,
2018, to €1.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This was primarily due to higher income tax
expenses in Sweden, driven by accruals for non-deductible tax relating to previous years, and higher tax expenses
in Italy primarily driven by differences in timing of accrued taxes, which decreased our income tax benefits.

_Materials and Consumables Used_

primarily due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, which contributed €15.7 million to our material and
consumables used from September 7, 2017 to September 30, 2017. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge
Acquisition, expenses for materials and consumables would have decreased by €2.8 million, or 1.2%, driven by
the disposal of Selecta’s operations in three Baltic countries completed on March 14, 2017, which accounted for
€6.2 million of this expense in the previous year.

_Employee Benefits Expense_

Employee benefits expense decreased by €5.5 million, or 2.3%, from €234.1 million for the year ended
September 30, 2016, to €228.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This decrease was primarily due
to a reduction in the number of FTEs in all four regions (other than Germany in the Central region), which
contributed to employee expense savings. FTE reductions were implemented for both field-force and
administrative staff, notably IT as a consequence of the outsourcing of the IT infrastructure. The Pelican Rouge
Acquisition accounted for €12.6 million of employee benefits expense from September 7, 2017, to September 30,
2017, and Selecta’s operations in the Baltics countries accounted for €1.8 million for the year ended
September 30, 2016. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Baltics disposal, employee
benefit expense decreased by 7.0%.

_Depreciation and Amortization Expense_

Depreciation and amortization expense increased by €1.2 million, or 1.3%, from €92.0 million for the year
ended September 30, 2016, to €93.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily
due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, which contributed €4.1 million to our depreciation and amortization
expense from September 7, 2017, to September 30, 2017. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition
and the Baltics disposal, depreciation and amortization expense would have decreased by €2.9 million, or 3.1%,
primarily as a result of a reduction to the PoS park, compared to the previous year.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Other operating expenses increased by €24.2 million, or 11.7%, from €206.2 million for the year ended
September 30, 2016, to €230.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to
the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and integration related advisory costs. In addition, IT outsourcing and ERP
development expenses contributed €5.3 million to our other operating expenses. Additionally, vending fees also
increased by €3.4 million to €88.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, due to an increase in public
sales. Vending fees, as a percentage of public revenue, increased by 0.5%.

_Finance Costs_

Finance costs increased by €17.9 million, or 20.9%, from €85.8 million for the year ended September 30,
2016 to €103.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to a €4.9 million
increase in non-cash interest charge on shareholder loans, financing transaction costs directly attributable to the
Pelican Rouge Acquisition, and foreign exchange losses.

_Finance Income_

Finance income increased by €3.1 million, or 70.5%, from €4.4 million for the year ended September 30,
2016, to €7.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to a change in fair
value of derivative financial instruments.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our principal sources of funds have been cash generated from our operating activities and borrowings under
the Revolving Credit Facility. Our principal uses of cash are to fund debt service obligations, working capital and
capital expenditures. As of June 30, 2019, we had cash and cash equivalents of €77.8 million.

Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows. Our ability
to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general
economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk Factors.”

In addition, we have access to the Revolving Credit Facility to service our working capital and general
corporate needs. The continued availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions,
including ongoing compliance with a maintenance covenant tested quarterly as described further under
“Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings
under the Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we
cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future
debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, or to fund
our other liquidity needs.

nine months ended June 30, 2018 to €71.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was
partially due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which contributed €11.5 million to operating
cash flows for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase
was partly offset by the impact of the disposal of Custompack Ltd. Without giving effect to acquisitions and
disposals over the periods, the increase in operating cash flows for the nine months June 30, 2019, was primarily
due to a decrease in losses before income tax combined with a decrease in cash outflow due to changes in
working capital.

_Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2017 and 2018_

Net cash flows from operating activities increased by €43.2 million, or 43.2%, from €99.9 million for the
year ended September 30, 2017 to €143.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was
primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, including synergies achieved
in employee expenses and overall operating expense.

Net cash flows from operating activities increased by €19.7 million, or 24.6%, from €80.2 million for the

We estimate that we will require gross capital expenditures of approximately €100 million per year on PoS
to support our current PoS park and revenue levels, in addition to capital expenditure for vehicles, IT and other
equipment, of which approximately €20 million are expected to be financed through finance leases. In addition,
we believe that we will require approximately €6 million of PoS gross capital expenditures to support each
additional per cent of revenue growth. Our estimates with respect to future capital expenditure requirements may
vary based on changes in our product, concept and segment mix.

As our capital expenditure requirements vary from year to year based on different capital intensity in
different business segments, specific reinvestment requirements in relation to new business, levels of capital
expenditure funded through new PoS versus refurbished PoS and specific initiatives to develop telemetry and
cashless payment technologies, among other factors, we cannot assure you that our level of capital expenditure
will not increase significantly in the future. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our business
_requires capital expenditures that may divert significant cash flow from other investments or uses, including debt_
_servicing.”_

**Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements**

Our off-balance sheet liabilities relate primarily to land, buildings and vehicles under various operating
lease agreements. As of June 30, 2019, we recorded expenses of €37.3 million for payments under operating
lease agreements not recorded on our balance sheet and expenses in relation to property, plants, equipment and
vehicles (excluding vending fees). As a result of the implementation of IFRS 16 beginning October 1, 2019, such
agreements will have to be recognized on the balance sheet.

Except as described above, we are not party to any off-balance sheet arrangements that have, or are
reasonably likely to have, a current or future material effect on our financial condition, revenue or expenses,
results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditure or capital resources.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk**

In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of market risks including credit risk, interest
rate risk and liquidity risk. We monitor and manage these risks as a part of our overall risk management. The
following section discusses the significant financial risks to which we are exposed. This discussion does not
address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See
“Risk Factors” and note 30 to our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate
because of changes in market interest rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relate
primarily to our long-term debt obligations with floating rate interests.

82


-----

The Revolving Credit Facility and the Floating Rate Notes bear interest at variable rates. While we may
enter into hedging agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we hedge may
not be satisfactory or may fail to adequately protect us from changes in market interest rates.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss resulting from counterparty failure to repay or service debt owed to us
according to the contractual terms or obligations. We are exposed to credit risk on our trade receivables,
non-current other financial assets and cash and cash equivalents.

Trade receivables are subject to credit limits and ongoing credit evaluations in all of our subsidiaries. Due to
our large geographic presence and large base of customers, we are not exposed to material concentrations of
credit risk on our trade receivables and have no significant exposure to credit risk with any single counterparty.
In addition, due the nature of our operations, a significant portion of our revenue is received in cash.

We do not believe we are exposed to significant credit risk on our cash and cash equivalents as these are
spread over several financial institutions in different countries.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk of not being able to fulfill present or future obligations if we do not have sufficient
funds available to meet such obligations at the time they become due. Liquidity risk arises mostly in relation to
cash flows generated and used in working capital and from financing activities, particularly by servicing our
debt, in terms of both interest and capital, and our payment obligations relating to our ordinary business
activities. We manage liquidity risk by continuously monitoring our expected cash flows and working capital
levels and ensuring that adequate borrowing facilities are maintained.

We have several thresholds and approval requirements for borrowing and investing as well as for using
derivative financial instruments. In general, subsidiaries may not borrow in their respective local currency
without the approval of our Chief Financial Officer. The subsidiaries may also not hedge their foreign currency
exposures without the approval of our Chief Financial Officer. Wherever possible, we require that subsidiaries
repatriate all their excess cash and bank balances to Group finance companies to allow the Group to ensure that
adequate funds are made available across the Group as necessary.

**_Foreign Currency Risk_**

Since each of our subsidiaries invoices its customers in the functional currency in which that subsidiary
operates, and since the significant part of its cost base is also denominated in its functional currency, our
exposure to currency risk is not significant.

Translation exposure arises from the consolidation of operations whose functional currency is not the euro
in our financial statements which are presented in euro. Previously, in order to minimize our exposure to
translation risk, we had established the borrowings and related interest payments in the four main currencies in
which we operate, namely EUR, CHF, GBP and SEK, in order to effect a natural hedge between our income and
interest expenses. As of June 30, 2019 €1,163 million of our Existing Notes and our borrowings under the
Revolving Credit Facility were denominated in EUR, 225 million in CHF and 34 million in GBP, and changes in
foreign exchange rates will therefore give rise to foreign exchange exposure. While we may enter into hedging
agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we hedge may not be satisfactory
or may fail to adequately protect us from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

**_Commodity Risk_**

We are exposed to commodity price risk because of coffee price fluctuations. Some of these fluctuations can
be passed on to customers through price increases in line with contractual conditions. In order to manage risks
from fluctuations in commodities prices, we secure the requirements for green bean for periods of up to six
months by instructing the relevant supplier to source the required green beans to cover certain production lots at a
specific price. With certain strategic suppliers, we enter into longer-term agreements with agreed price
adjustment mechanisms that reflect developments in commodity prices. We periodically assess the economic
impact of hedging coffee bean prices but consider the hedging cost too high to make hedging financially
attractive. However, while we do not enter into hedging instruments with respect to coffee prices, coffee volumes
are committed with suppliers between one and six months in advance depending on current green bean coffee
prices and expectations of future price development.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

Our Historical Financial Statements and the accompanying notes contain information that is pertinent to the
discussion and analysis of our results of operations and financial condition set forth above. The preparation of
our Historical Financial Statements requires management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that
affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses and the
disclosure of contingent liabilities at the reporting date. These estimates and assumptions are based on historical
experience and other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. However, actual results
may differ from these estimates and assumptions. The estimates and assumptions that have a significant risk of
causing a material adjustment to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in future periods are summarized
below. For a more detailed description of our significant accounting policies, see note 3 of our 2018 Consolidated
Financial Statements.

**_Goodwill and Intangible Assets with Indefinite Useful Lives_**

The cash-generating unit to which goodwill is allocated and other intangible assets with indefinite useful
lives are tested for impairment annually and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. The
recoverable amounts of cash generating units and intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are determined
based on their values in use. These calculations require the use of estimates and assumptions consistent with the
most up-to-date business plans that have been formally approved by management.

**_Customer Contracts_**

Intangible assets resulting from the acquisition of customer contracts in a business combination have a finite
useful life and are amortized over the determined life of 10 or 15 years. We actively monitor retention rates on
customer contracts and consider other relevant factors which may provide an indication of impairment.

**_Employee Benefits_**

The present value of the pension obligations depends on a variety of factors that are estimated annually by
independent actuaries using a number of assumptions, including the discount rate to be applied to determine the
present value of defined benefit obligations. In determining the appropriate discount rate, we consider the interest
rates of high-quality corporate bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits will be paid, and
that have terms to maturity approximating the terms of the related pension liability.

**_Deferred Income Tax Assets_**

Deferred income tax assets on unused tax losses carried forward are recognized to the extent it is probable
that there will be future taxable profits against which the losses can be offset. The assessment of recoverability of
the recognized deferred income tax assets is based on assumptions regarding future profits and is derived from
the latest budgets and business plans of the Group.

**_Provisions_**

Provisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a
past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable
estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. The amount recognized as a provision is based on
management’s best estimate of the consideration required to settle the obligation at the end of the reporting
period, taking into account the risks and uncertainties surrounding the obligation. Provisions for warranties are
ordinarily determined by product line and are based on statistics including the likelihood of a breakdown
occurring and the average cost of repair or replacement.

**_Sales Estimates_**

Where sales are based on consumption in the PoS, there may be a timing difference between the date on
which the cash was last collected from the PoS and the date on which the sales readings were taken. In this case,
an estimate of the sales between the date of the last cash collection or the last PoS reading and the end of the
period is made. The estimate is based on historical sales trends in respect of the specific customer sites and PoS.
The estimated amount of sales which have been neither collected in cash nor invoiced to customers are recorded
as accrued income and uncollected cash in points-of-sale.

84


-----

**_Inventories_**

Food and beverage inventories which have passed their sell by date are fully provided against. Similarly,
where the level of food and beverage inventories held exceeds the sales expected to be achieved before the sell
by date, a provision is made for the excess inventory held. Provisions for equipment in inventory are recorded
against PoS in inventory according to the age of the PoS. Provisions for spare parts held in inventory are
calculated according to the inventory turnover ratio.

**Description of Adjustments to the Unaudited Aggregated Non-GAAP Financial Information**

The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been derived by applying certain
adjustments to each of our Historical Financial Statements and the financial statements of the Pelican Rouge
Group, the Argenta Group and the Express Vending Group for the relevant periods in order to aid in their
comparability. Such adjustments fall within two categories, adjusting for the scope of the financial information
included (constant scope adjustments) and the exchange rates used in respect of the financial information
recorded in currencies other than euro (constant currency adjustments), as described in detail below.

**_Constant Scope Adjustments_**

The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to give effect to the
transactions described below, as if they had occurred on October 1, 2015, to the extent they were not already
reflected in the relevant period:

   - the acquisition by Selecta AG of Pelican Rouge Group, which occurred on September 7, 2017, and
contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 6, 2017;

   - the acquisition by TopCo of Argenta Group, which occurred on February 2, 2018, and contributes to
the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to February 1, 2018;

   - the acquisition by Selecta AG of Express Vending Group, which occurred on August 17, 2018, and
contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to August 16, 2018;

   - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Sweden, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes
to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016;

   - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Germany, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes
to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016;

   - the disposal of Selecta subsidiaries in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which occurred in March 2017,
and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 30, 2016;

   - the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which occurred on September 19, 2018, and contributes to the
adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 18, 2018.

While the Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to reflect acquisitions
that we consider significant, it does not reflect all acquisitions we have completed during the relevant period. We
categorize acquisitions of businesses with less than €3.0 million in gross sales for the twelve months preceding
such acquisition as part of our organic growth. Consequently, transactions involving such acquisitions are not
included in the constant scope adjustments to our Historical Financial Statements.

In addition to the above, adjustments have been made to align the fiscal period of acquired companies with
Selecta’s financial year and also as a result of accounting policy differences and reclassifications, as further
detailed below under “—Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) and Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)” and “—Adjusted

Belgium, Norway and Denmark, mainly from an increase in trading sales and, to a lesser extent,
successful rollouts in our semi-public business in Sweden and Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth in
or public business in Belgium and Denmark.

2018, increased by €5.6 million (without giving effect to harmonization of vending fees) compared to

growth in Austria and, to a lesser extent, in Switzerland and Germany. We also benefitted from an
increase in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in France in our public business channel, partly offset by
lower sales in the workplace and semi-public channels due to a decrease in sales from legacy Pelican

**_Comparison of Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2019, to the Nine Months_**
**_Ended June 30, 2018_**

Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, amounted to €201.0 million, an
increase of €17.8 million, or 9.7% compared to Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €183.2 million for the nine
months ended June 30, 2018. We achieved synergies and cost savings of €24 million for the nine months ended
June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. We also undertook significant growth
investments over the period, primarily consisting of investments in (i) our sales force to drive organic growth;
(ii) innovation, mainly new concepts and digitalization; (iii) infrastructure and (iv) our support functions such as
legal, finance and human resources, to activate strategic business partnership; and (v) off-balance sheet financing
projects to implement our strategy of optimizing capital expenditures. This increase was also due to an increase
of €2.4 million in Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the nine
months ended June 30, 2018, due to bolt-on acquisitions, mainly in Italy, Switzerland, Spain, Germany and the
UK. Below is a discussion of drivers for the increase in our Adjusted EBITDA (CS &CC) for the nine months
ended June 30, 2019 compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018:

   - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the nine_
months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €5.3 million compared to the nine months ended June 30,
2018, primarily due to an increase in revenue in Spain and from Express Vending, as well as cost
savings and rightsizing personnel and overhead expenses reductions in the UK.

   - _North. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the North region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019,_
increased by €15.8 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to higher
revenue across the region over the period, including from our roaster business which benefitted from
favorable coffee prices.

   - _Central. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the Central region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019,_
decreased by €4.7 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018. This decrease was due to our
results of operations in France, where our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended
June 30, 2019, declined by €8.5 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This
decrease was partly offset by our results in Switzerland driven by higher revenue and operational
excellence initiatives.

   - _Headquarters. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) at our Headquarters for the nine months ended June 30,_
2019, increased by €1.5 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to our
leaner corporate structure.

Our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margin for the nine months ended June 30, 2019 (calculated as Adjusted
EBITDA (CS & CC) divided by Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)), remained stable compared to the nine
months ended June 30, 2018, due to the usually low margin in trade sales being offset by procurement synergy
savings as well as pricing and category managements initiatives.

**INDUSTRY**

**Leading Route-Based Unattended Self Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in Europe**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service and convenience food provider in the European
region, with an installed base of over 475,000 PoS. We operate in 16 countries, covering approximately 95% of
European GDP and approximately 78% of the population. According to OC&C and our internal estimates, we
have the number one or number two market position in the Unattended SSR Market (as defined below) in all but
one of the Focus Countries (as defined below). Overall, we have the number one or number two market position
in ten of our markets. Moreover, we are number one in Europe with approximately 10% market share. We
believe that our adjusted revenue (on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended
September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5 times higher than the second largest competitor.

**Market Opportunity of the Convenience Market**

According to OC&C, the total out-of-home food and drink market is €845 billion. This includes all spend at
restaurants, cafes and bars, and unattended self-service retail items. Within the total out-of-home food and
beverage market, we operate in the Addressable Market (as defined below) of €42 billion, consisting of all
convenience spend on hot and cold beverages, and snacks. The Unattended Self Service Retail Market is a subset
of the Addressable Market, and is estimated to be €15 billion. It includes both Unattended Self Service Retail (at
work and on-the-go) and capsule coffee at the office.

**_Definition and Overview of the Core Unattended Self-Service Retail and Addressable Markets_**

We operate within the Unattended SSR Market, which can be categorized into two main segments:
Workplace which includes private segment and OCS, and on-the-go which includes public and semi-public
segment. We estimate that the Unattended SSR Market is a €15 billion market in the Focus Countries. Through
the continued development and expansion of new concepts, such as MicroMarkets, we are increasingly involved
in the broader addressable convenience market (the “Addressable Market”), which spans the Unattended SSR
Market, as well as the broader convenience market with other retail formats (e.g. street stalls, kiosks and
convenience stores), and has a market size of €42 billion in the Focus Countries. The Addressable Market can
also be categorized into the two segments of workplace and on-the-go. Within the Addressable Market, in
addition to Unattended SSR Market, the workplace segment includes cafeterias and the on-the-go segment
includes convenience foodservice and packaged foods.

The workplace segment aims at improving the experience of people at work, for example by enhancing
employee engagement, satisfaction, and productivity in the work environment. Through vending and office
coffee services, unattended self-service retailers, such as us, service private businesses and corporate offices in
places generally not accessible by other retail formats.

Unattended self-service retailers that enter into three to five year contacts with corporate customers receive
proceeds through sale of goods from impulse and coffee machines, servicing fees and revenues from sales of
coffee beans and other consumables. We pay rent to selected large private customers based on percentage of
sales, a flat fee, or a combination thereof.

The workplace segment accounted for approximately 36% (by value) of the Addressable Market in the
Focus Countries in 2017. In addition to self-service PoS, this segment includes cafeteria and capsules, whereby
cafeterias include hot drinks and snacks, but exclude warm lunches, and capsules include machines and capsules
provided by the employer in small and medium office environments.

The on-the-go segment aims to enhance the consumer experience by providing tailored coffee and snacking
offerings in public (e.g. train and gas stations or airports) and semi-public locations (e.g. hospitals and public
schools). Contracts typically range between five to ten years. We receive proceeds from the sales of goods from
PoS and pay rent to customers based on a percentage of sales, a flat fee, or a combination thereof.

The on-the-go segment accounted for approximately 64% (by value) of the Addressable Market in the Focus
Countries in 2017. In addition to self-service PoS, this segment includes convenience foodservice and packaged
food retailing. Convenience foodservice includes products prepared for take-away/ready-to-eat, hot drinks
(especially coffee), as well as value-add drinks sold in street stalls, kiosks and specialized coffee shops. Packaged
food retailing includes packaged food, confectionary items, snacks and soft drinks sold in convenience stores and
forecourt retailers.

Within the Unattended SSR Market, approximately 85% (by value) is in the workplace segment in the Focus
Countries in 2017. This segment includes PoS located in private businesses and is comprised of (i) fully operated
PoS offering hot drinks and impulse items (cold drinks and snacks) (i.e., private self-service retail), and
(ii) coffee machines (often table-top) operated (cleaned and refilled) by the employer located in private
businesses (i.e., OCS).

The remainder of the Unattended SSR Market (approximately 15% by value) in the Focus Countries in 2017
lies in the on-the-go segment. This segment includes the sale of hot drinks and impulse items at public locations
(e.g. train stations, gas stations) and semi-public locations (e.g. hospitals, universities).

The trade segment provides a full suite of services and coffee and coffee related products to customers.
Selecta receives proceeds from the sales of roasted coffee beans, PoS, other goods, and third party technical
servicing.

**Overview of the Self-service Retail Value Chain**

Self-service retail operators distribute food and drink products to consumers through their PoS portfolio.
While consumers consume the products, self-service retail operators contract primarily with the facility
management functions of private entities (e.g. offices, factories) and infrastructure functions of public entities
(e.g. rail stations, airports). Through contractual agreements, customers compensate the self-service retail
operators for providing a full or partial service. The value chain for the self-service retail industry includes
several key participants and areas:

Our operations span across the value chain of the Unattended SSR Market. We purchase machines for our
customers, install them at their premises and manage sourcing and stocking of the food and beverages on behalf
of our customers. We provide quality coffee brands and convenient food and beverage concepts, including
premium coffee concepts through our own brand Pelican Rouge and our Starbucks and Lavazza partnerships. We
also offer cleaning, maintenance and technical support services, which can be customized to individual
customers’ preferences. In addition to our self-service retail operations, we sell machines, machine parts and
products independently of service arrangements.
