**Overview of Self-service Retail Business Models**

Business models can be differentiated depending on the level of services provided. Additionally, some selfservice retail operators offer the sale of ingredients (such as coffee beans, ground coffee, milk (powder) and
sugar), machines and machine parts as well as technical services. The provided level of service typically varies
with PoS density which determines profitability levels. The workplace segment with larger companies (with
more than 250 employees) typically provides for large scale full-service contracts. Self-operated PoS are
typically prevalent in smaller companies (with 250 or fewer employees) in the workplace segment, as well as at
gas stations in the on-the-go segment that are too remote to be fully operated by a self-service retail operator. The
detailed overview of business models is as follows:

**Full Service Model** The self-service retail operator owns or leases and is responsible for the
procurement and placement of PoS, stocking and restocking of items, and ongoing
maintenance.
The self-service retail operator pays a fee (e.g. based on sold cups, or a flat fee) to
the B2B contractor.
End consumers typically pay for convenience food and beverage at the PoS, with
sales directly collected from the self-service retail operator on a consumption
basis.
**Partial Service Model** The self-service retail operator provides the PoS and ingredients and receives a
monthly fee, with customers responsible for cleaning and refilling the PoS
themselves.
**Supply/Technical Model** The self-service retail operator sells machines (both replacements and to new
customers) and ingredients to customers without any service element and offers
technical service contracts for machines.

As these business models all require self-service retail operators to make regular visits to customer sites,
maintaining dense clusters of customers in conjunction with dynamic route-planning for merchandizers and
technicians visiting those sites are key for profitability. Telemetry devices installed in PoS provide self-service
retail operators with real-time data from the PoS, which is then used to plan bespoke routes to PoS that require a
visit, ensure no stock-outs and reduce time needed for merchandisers as with telemetry they already have
pre-kitted sets.

We operate across all three types of business models described above with a focus on the full service model,
which together with the partial service model accounted for 84% of our revenue for the year ended September 30,
2018, and the supply/technical model accounted for the remaining 16%.

Self-service retail services are typically provided to private, public and semi-public customers. Private
customers generally operate within private or relatively restricted locations such as offices and factories. Public
customers have properties that are generally located in more widely accessible locations such as railway stations,
and airports. PoS are also provided to customers in semi-public locations such as universities, schools, health
clubs, and hospitals.

We focus on three types of PoS: (i) hot beverages (predominantly coffee, hot chocolate, tea) free standing
PoS and table top machines; (ii) cold beverages (cans and bottles) in closed front PoS; and (iii) snacks, cold
drinks, fresh foods and non-food products in glass front PoS.

While all of these products are available through several other distribution channels (e.g. supermarkets,
coffee shops), PoS offer a value proposition focused around convenience for both consumers and customers at
locations where other distribution channels might not be available. Specifically, we provide consumers with
“24/7” access to products at particularly convenient points of sale in private, public and semi-public locations.
Furthermore, in the workplace segment we also operate MicroMarkets with an enlarged product portfolio on a
much larger area which provide us with an additional route to market which is gaining traction across Europe.

Self-service retail operators such as Selecta typically earn revenue from their customers via long-term
contracts which provide a high degree of revenue visibility due to stable consumption patterns of consumers.
While the term of each contract varies, private contracts are typically for a period of three to five years, and
public contracts are typically for a period of five to ten years. Self-service retail operators generate revenue based
on their specific business models and the range of services offered. Illustratively, a self-service retail provider
operating within a private setting with a full service business model would earn revenues from the sale of
products with prices agreed at the outset of the contract and adjusted based on a mechanism such as a price index.

99


-----

Operators generally also generate fixed service/maintenance fees from their public and private customers.
Volume-based rebates are typically agreed with larger multi-site customers. PoS in private settings operate either
on a free vend or pay vend basis. On a free vend basis, the customer subsidizes the cost for consumers which then
do not need to make payments themselves. Alternatively, on a pay vend basis, consumers purchase items using
cash or a form of cashless payment system without any subsidies from the customer. Products are sold in public
settings on a pay vend basis and providers are typically free to set and adapt product selling prices, but a provider
typically pays a fee (rent) to the customer for occupying the customer’s premises.

**Industry Drivers and Trends**

**_Consumer Trends Driving Growth_**

We operate in a market where future growth is fueled by positive underlying mega trends such as increasing
share of out-of-home food and beverage consumption, premiumization, and convenience. We also benefit from
overall GDP growth, although lower than our own market growth.

_Macroeconomic conditions: Selecta benefits from the supportive macro-economic conditions driving_
consumer spending growth, particularly out-of-home Food & Beverages. Furthermore, the increase in workforce
and hours-spend-at-work is driving overall consumption at the workplace.

_Premiumization: The premium coffee growth in coffee on-the-go and at the workplace drives pricing above_
inflation. Additionally, the shift towards healthy products supports higher prices in snacks and cold drinks.

_Shift toward convenience: As consumers desire convenience, we are poised to benefit from preferences for_
fast and local consumption. With an increasing focus on mobility, consumers prefer convenience formats while
spending more time and money on-the-go.

**_Industry Trends_**

We believe that the key drivers and trends impacting market growth in the Unattended SSR Market include
the following:

_Increased Workforce and Hours Spent In the Office_

The workplace segment is supported by growth in employment statistics, with all but one of the following
countries seeing an increase in total workforce numbers between 2012 and 2017: France, Germany, Italy, Spain,
Sweden, Switzerland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom (the “Focus Countries”). Specifically, according
to OC&C, total workforce has grown at a CAGR of 1.4% in Sweden, 1.4% in the UK and 1.3% in France, Spain,
and Switzerland between 2012 and 2017. Collectively across all Focus Countries, the number of hours spent at
the office has grown at a CAGR of 0.9% between 2012 and 2017.

_Time Spent On-the-Go_

Due to overall mobility trends (rise in number of business and leisure commuters), consumers spend more
time (and money) on-the-go and prefer formats that offer desired products and quality fast (e.g. no lines, easy
payment options). The rise in domestic trips per capita is leading to increased number of encounters with PoS
and stores selling convenience products at public locations, increasing the demand for on-the-go convenience
products. Across all product categories and countries, surveys indicate that consumers on-the-go value the quick
transaction nature and convenient location of self-service retail vis-à-vis other retailing formats.

_Increased Consumer Spend on Out-of-Home Food and Beverage_

Out-of-home consumer spending on food and beverage items has been rising across each of the Focus
Countries. Between 2012 and 2014, out-of-home consumer spending increased at a CAGR of 1.8%. This growth
has intensified between 2014 and 2017 to 4.2%, driven primarily by large increases across the Focus Countries.
OC&C estimates that this spending growth will continue between 2018 and 2022. Increases in impulse
purchases, in particular from public points of sale have predominantly contributed to this growth.

_Available Locations_

Although the number of public locations has remained stable, there has been an increase in the number of
locations where operators can place self-service PoS, including offices. This increased availability also increases
consumer exposure to self-service retail points of sale, which drives growth in impulse purchases.

_Premiumization_

An increase in premium coffee drinking culture is driving on-the-go and workplace segment growth.
Furthermore, the premiumization trend (especially in coffee), in combination with a trend toward customized
products are driving average prices of premium food and beverages. Thus, increasing prices per vend and rising
share of premium coffee PoS underline the premiumization trend and consumers’ willingness to pay for it despite
the availability of free alternatives at work. The chart below illustrates the increase in the percentage of PoS
serving bean-to-cup coffee in each Focus Country.

**_Comprehensive Product & Service Offerings_**

We offer a wide variety of products, which range from coffee and hot drinks, cold drinks, snacks, to fresh
food. We have a diversified portfolio of attractive coffee brands across all price points. These include premium
global brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza, local specialties such as Pelican Rouge, and other third party
private labels.

Through these products, we have the ability to offer a suite of three main service capabilities: full service,
partial service, and supply/technical. Selecta’s full service includes a comprehensive package that includes
installations of Selecta PoS, regular filling and cleaning, and technical maintenance. Partial service targets
smaller office environments, and offers machines, ingredients, and consumables. Clients are responsible for
cleaning and refilling. In supply/technical, we provide the machines, ingredients and consumables. We offer
technical support services under separate contracts that are negotiated with the client. The machines are sold to
the customer in this case.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

Although there is no directly comparable competitor, we face competition from other similar traditional
self-service retail operators (both on a local / regional and national / international level), including those run by
contract caterers and facility management companies, fast-moving consumer goods, capsule, coffee bars, as well
as coffee tower companies and providers of alternative formats. Groups of key competitors in the Unattended
SSR Market are elaborated on below.

106


-----

_Traditional Self-service Retail Specialists_

Our main competitors are traditional self-service retail operators. The European Unattended SSR Market is
largely mature and is characterized by a large number of industry participants. The industry is fragmented with
few players of national scale and a long tail of small players per market, indicating the relatively low barriers to
entry at a local level but high barriers to scale. Self-service retail operators offer their services across workplace
and on-the-go segments. In the workplace segment, they focus on larger businesses (blue and white collar) with
high throughput and multiple PoS at one location given the high density required for efficiency in refilling. In the
on-the-go segment, self-service retail operators offer convenience products at locations where footfall for laborintensive formats is too low, retail space is insufficient, or opening hours limit other formats.

Given the high density required to operate PoS portfolio profitably, the Unattended SSR Market has
relatively high barriers to scale. There is a limited set of players comparable to us in terms of brand, scale,
product width and multi-regional presence. Regional specialists are competitive locally, but have a limited ability
to serve national/international customers (e.g. gas stations, public train stations) or offer a full product range. We
believe that the domestic key competitors in the Focus Countries include local players, such as IVS (mainly in
Italy), Daltys (only in France) and Maas (only in the Netherlands).

_Contract Caterers and Facility Management Providers_

Contract caterers and facility management providers can offer a one-stop service at a cost advantage, with
PoS typically being operated by a customer’s own cafeteria staff. However, complex machine operations
typically require trained technicians, leading to the credibility of caterers being increasingly questioned, e.g. in
terms of refilling fresh food and of costs and expenses. As a result, increasingly more, contract caterers and
facility management providers are partnering with self-service retail specialists to provide these services for a
fee. Key players include Aramark in Belgium and Germany, Compass in the UK and Elior in Spain.

_Vertically Integrated Self-service Retail Providers_

Vertically Integrated self-service retail providers represent a small group of mostly coffee and soft drinks
producers, who as an extension to their core drinks production operations also ventured into Unattended SSR
Market. However, they did so mostly as a brand extension and as a means of direct access and communication
with final consumers. As a result their product offering is usually limited or in some cases strictly restricted to
their own product portfolio (e.g. coffee or soft drinks). While they occupy a portion of the market, Vertically
Integrated self-service retail providers cannot fully compete as traditional self-service retail specialists, who
provide a considerably wider portfolio of brands, product offering and capabilities. Key players include JDE,
Dallmayr and Lavazza Professional (former Mars drinks). Coffee towers are also in this group and are operated
by coffee shop chains like Costa. Competitive pressures on traditional self-service retail specialists from coffee
towers is limited to urban areas. One of the key competitors is Costa Express in the United Kingdom (now part of
Coca-Cola, which is a competitor for our coffee offering in the UK, but we are still servicing their machines and
distributing their cold beverages in our PoS).

_Other Formats_

Other formats typically offer a wider range of food and beverages, including healthy and fresh options.
These formats typically require high footfall to be profitable and compensate for high fees. Compared to these
formats, self-service retail operators can maintain better proximity to consumers, in particular during short
changing times (e.g. train station platforms). Key competitors include Tesco Express, REWE to Go, 7-Eleven,
and Relay.

preferences and maximize revenue opportunities, which improve consumer experience and customer satisfaction.
We also provide cleaning, maintenance, and technical support services which can be customized based on
individual customer needs and preferences, even when we do not enter into a full self-service retail service
arrangement with the customer. In addition to our unattended self-service and coffee roasting operations, we also
sell coffee and machines, including to hotels, restaurants and cafés, and machine parts and products independent
of self-service retail service arrangements.

Due to the predictable nature of our business and the length of our customer contracts, we believe we are
able to achieve high revenue visibility. We benefit from diversified revenue streams secured by multi-year
contracts derived from a large and loyal customer base across private and public sector in 2018 and a 100%
retention rate with our top ten customers over that period. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that our average
private customer contract term is three to five years, and our average public customer contract term is five to ten
years. Moreover, the maintenance and cleaning services we offer as part of our self-service retail services provide
us with an additional source of high margin revenues.

Innovation and technology are also key drivers of our success, and we benefit from our track record of
innovation leadership both in terms of technology upgrades such as cashless payment, touchscreen user
interfaces and telemetry, as well as in terms of unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to
drive daily revenue per PoS and open new routes-to-market.

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown organically as well as through acquisitions. On

nine of the 15 markets in which we operated at that time, making us the market leader by revenue in France,
Spain, the United Kingdom, and Belgium. In addition, on February 2, 2018, we completed the acquisition of the

**Our Competitive Strengths**

We believe that we benefit from the key competitive strengths listed below.

**_Business Proposition Offering Unmatched Convenience_**

We offer consumers a wide variety of on-the-go food products for everyday consumption and impulse
purchases, with a strong focus on coffee, at all hours of the day and every day of the year thanks to our
unattended, 24/7, fully automated, convenience retail concept. Our concept targets captive environments and is
economically viable even in low footfall locations due to our minimal operational costs compared with
traditional retail concepts. Our ability to sell products in convenient retail locations and our high level of
customer service has led to an average overall customer retention based on revenue of approximately 95.9% for
the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and approximately 92.5% and 94.4% for each of the years ended
September 30, 2017 and 2018, respectively. We believe that the quality of our service levels and our customer
relationship management contribute to customer loyalty, leading to an average relationship of approximately 15
years with our 10 largest customers. In addition, contract renewals with our existing long-term customers are
typically more profitable than entering into a contract with a new customer, due to savings on equipment and
other capital expenditures and customer acquisition costs. Our costs associated with new customers are followed
by predictable revenue streams and we usually recoup these costs within two years. We have a scalable routebased business model that we are able to apply across the 16 countries in which we operate with the same key
success factors, to drive growth in customers, daily revenue per PoS and profitability. For example, following the
Argenta Acquisition in 2018, we have replicated Argenta’s MicroMarkets operating model in other countries
such as Switzerland and the Netherlands. Our focus on out-of-home impulse consumption limits our exposure to
competition from online retailers and offerings.

**_Well Positioned to Take Advantage of Premium Coffee and Out-of-Home Consumption Growth_**

We operate in our Addressable Market, estimated at €42 billion in 2017, in our Focus Countries. Within the
Addressable Market, we focus on the Unattended SSR Market which has a market size of approximately
€16 billion in our 16 countries of operations, of which approximately €15 billion arises in the Focus Countries.
Our Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.1% between 2012 and 2017, reaching a total value of
approximately €40.5 billion in the Focus Countries and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.1% reaching
€47.1 billion by 2022. This trend has been driven by a positive macro-economic backdrop with an increase in
GDP and stable employment levels, which have led to increased spending in the workplace channel. In addition,
we believe that an increasing preference for drinking premium coffee and out-of-home consumption, increased
mobility, and the desire for easy availability of healthy and quality products is driving consumers towards our
pan-European on-the-go self-service retail offerings. For example, sales of coffee within the Addressable Market
has grown at a CAGR of 2.8% between 2012 to 2017, reaching €16.0 billion, and is expected to grow at a CAGR
of 3.9%, reaching €19.4 billion by 2022.

Moreover, the growing trend toward premium brands has created a shift in consumer emphasis on high
quality product offerings, including organic and name-brand coffee, a trend which we are addressing with our

110


-----

Starbucks, and Lavazza brand partnerships. For example, we are able to offer consumers a premium hot drinks
experience, both in the workplace and on-the-go through our long-standing partnership with Starbucks. As of
June 30, 2019, we have installed approximately 1,964 Starbucks concepts across Europe, and the price of a
coffee sold in our Starbucks on-the-go concept is between 20% to 90% higher than a coffee sold in traditional
self-service PoS, and such trends for premium brands support our profitability. Similarly, through our partnership
with Lavazza we offer our customers and consumers additional options for a premium coffee experience. As of
June 30, 2019, we had over 15,637 PoS selling Lavazza coffee and we estimate that approximately 40,000 PoS
will serve Lavazza coffee in the long-term.

**_Leading Unattended Self-Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in the European Unattended SSR_**
**_Market with Growth above Market_**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in the
Unattended SSR Market, and had an estimated 10% market share by revenue in the Focus Countries for the year
ended December 30, 2017, compared to 6% over the same period in 2016. We believe that our adjusted revenue
(on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5
times that of the second largest market player. As of June 30, 2019, we had operations in 16 European countries,
which covered approximately 95% of European GDP and contain approximately 78% of the European
population. In 2016, we served over six million consumers per day, which we have nearly doubled to more than
ten million consumers served per day. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue
in 2017 in our ten core markets, and we estimate that this market data is still accurate as of the date of this
Offering Memorandum. Our sales in these markets represented 90.7% of our revenue for the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we operated a network of more than 475,000 active coffee and
convenience food and beverage self-service PoS, approximately 2.5 times the number of PoS of the second
largest market player. With regards to our suppliers, we believe we are the largest machine buyer in the highly
fragmented Unattended SSR Market, making us the customer of choice for our suppliers, which in turn provides
us with competitively priced procurement arrangements on, amongst other, a wide selection of market leading
machines.

The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We
are one of the very few operators on a pan-European level, which increases the appeal of our brands and
offerings with consumers and of our services and concepts with customers, as compared with our smaller
competitors. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in each of our three
geographic segments was split relatively evenly with Central accounting for 37%, North accounting for 26%, and
South, UK & Ireland accounting for 37%. This is in contrast to the second largest market player, over three
quarters of whose revenue in its last financial year was derived from Italy alone. In addition, the breadth of our
product portfolio enables us to better address consumers’ preferences across geographic segments, including
evolving market trends, and to provide a one-stop shop offering for our customers. Additionally, our established
brands and unique concepts differentiate us from our competitors and enable us to secure attractive and
comprehensive contracts with a variety of suppliers and premium brands, which help us maintain our high
market share.

**_Using Innovation and Technology to Drive Growth and Improve Margins_**

We use innovation and new technologies to drive our growth and improve margins, and we have a track
record of innovation leadership through continuous rollouts of upgrades to our PoS across all geographies.
Innovation and technology improve the consumer experience, enhance operational excellence and allow us to
further expand our route-based business model. Cashless payment systems and digital touchscreen user interfaces
that we are rolling out across our PoS park enhance the consumer experience by providing additional
accessibility and simplicity of use, thereby driving number of sales and average transaction size compared to
cash transactions. As of June 30, 2019, daily revenue per PoS equipped with cashless technology are on average
10% to 20% higher than PoS that only accept cash, and the average transaction value of products sold from
cashless PoS is between 5% to 10% higher, making cashless payment options an important driver in increasing
sales from existing PoS. As of June 30, 2019, 95% of our public PoS deployed cashless technology. Telemetry in
our PoS allows us to better adjust our pricing and product offerings to drive sales and to more efficiently monitor
inventory levels and determine maintenance requirements, which increases our route efficiency and operational
excellence, and thereby improves service quality and customer retention. As of June 30, 2019, we had telemetry
devices installed in approximately 95% of our public PoS. In addition to technological innovation, we also
continue to innovate and introduce new unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to adapt to
market and consumer trends, increase sales and improve profitability, while reducing capital expenditures.

**_Route-Based Business Model with High Density on the Last Mile_**

Our route-based business model combined with our size represents a distinct competitive advantage,
particularly on the last mile of service, which allows us to service and supply PoS at an optimized cost level,
thereby improving our profitability compared to other competitors. In addition, we continuously optimize the
density of our PoS to make routes more efficient, thereby reducing driving time and increasing our ability to
service more PoS per hour and more PoS per FTE. We are, therefore, able to offer more competitive pricing at
the same profitability point or the same levels of service at a lower price, as compared to less profitable smaller
regional players, thereby creating genuine barriers to match our scale. We also use data from our PoS equipped
with telemetry and our dedicated team of approximately 150 planners (as of June 30, 2019) to continuously
optimize our over 3,800 dense and cost-effective routes. As of June 30, 2019, our 4,900 route merchandizers and
1,400 route technicians were able to service their routes using a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. The map below
illustrates the location of each of our PoS, and shows the density of our route-based networks.

**_Scale Driven Business Model Creating Attractive Economics and Enhancing Established Market Presence_**

We have developed a business model with a cost advantage through economies of scale and high density,
and we believe it will be difficult for potential competitors to replicate the scale, breadth, and efficiency of our
organization. Our scale also enables us to deliver superior customer service by leveraging our knowledge of the
industry to provide customers and consumers with a comprehensive range of products and innovative service
offerings. These attributes lead to an estimated 5% to 15% EBITDA margin (as defined by and according to
OC&C) advantage over smaller competitors.

We deploy capital expenditures in order to retain and acquire new customers and do so by acquiring new
PoS and refurbishing our existing PoS in order to enhance returns on investment. Capital expenditure for new
PoS and refurbishment of existing PoS of the Group typically achieves a ROI ranging from 100% to 250%,
depending on the country, with the highest returns in the Netherlands, the UK and Switzerland. We have
consistently achieved efficiencies stemming from PoS park rationalization (which includes margin management,
relocating PoS to more profitable locations, and decreasing the types of PoS in use) and refurbishment. In
addition to the operational advantages explained above we also believe that given our scale we retain a cost
advantage over our competitors in terms of pricing from machine suppliers and that our in-house refurbishment
and maintenance capabilities also provide us a cost advantage.

**_Attractive Financial Profile with Organic Growth, Profitability and Cash Conversion Momentum_**

Our business has delivered consistent financial results with resilient Adjusted EBITDA margins and stable
cash flow generation, with a non-IFRS cash conversion (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) minus
Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS & CC), divided by Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)) of 46.7%, 45.9%, and
52.0% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, respectively, and 49.1% for the twelve months
ended June 30, 2019. Adjusted EBITDA minus net capital expenditures, divided by Adjusted EBITDA,
amounted to 38.2%, 42.5% and 50.8% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively, and

49.0% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta
Acquisition, and the Express Vending Acquisition, we have also benefited from significant cost synergies
including, among others, procurement savings, footprint optimization, headquarters integration, and price
harmonization and streamlining. As we continue to realize synergies, our efficiency improves and cash

Our strong market positions in key markets, coupled with our ongoing efforts to optimize PoS density and
operational efficiencies, increased technology penetration, as well as data analytics across all markets contribute
to further enhancing our financial profile and organic growth. Excluding France and the UK, we achieved

according to which we take decisions and run our business. We have identified the following key pillars driving
our strategy, as further described below.

**_Driving Performance Through Sales Excellence_**

The first line for growing our business and improving our margins is excellence in sales, as it is through

**_Further Developing Pricing and Category Management_**

We believe that there is a significant opportunity to increase daily revenue per PoS by improving pricing
and category management. We have initiated an analytical approach to support decision making and assess the
impact of pricing and category management across our footprint. With telemetry now equipped on most of our
public PoS, it allows us to analyze sales data and unlock pricing capabilities in ways previously unavailable to us.
We believe this gives us an opportunity to continuously optimize performance, with location specific product
assortment and pricing initiatives, allowing us to better manage margins on underperforming accounts, upsell our
services to B2B customers, and reduce leakage to competing local offerings. We expect pricing and category
management efforts to have a more than €10.0 million impact on revenue for our 2019 fiscal year.

**_Improving Operational Excellence_**

Our route-based business model benefits from the significant increases in productivity resulting from our
dense network of PoS and depots, and we are continuously optimizing route density through professional route
planning. We thereby leverage our focus on technology and innovation to further improve our operational
excellence. For example, the installation of telemetry capabilities in our PoS allows for dynamic route planning
and increased efficiency of our refillers by reducing preparation time and enabling the refiller to visit more PoS.
Density optimization is also a key consideration in our bolt-on acquisition program, and one of the key drivers of
synergy achievement.

Our operational excellence is also driven by our success in acquiring and integrating companies, such as
Pelican Rouge, Argenta and Express Vending. Led by an integration office reporting to the Board of Directors of
the Group, we have identified approximately €75 million in annualized procurement, SG&A and operational
synergies that are at being implemented and that we expect to be fully realized by the end of 2020, resulting in a
strong margin uplift. In terms of procurement, we expect to achieve up to €30 million of annualized synergies
from equipment, ingredients, bought-in goods, disposables, packaging and spares and the in-sourcing of coffee
production. SG&A synergies in an amount of up to €13 million include the consolidation of country and group
headquarters and the optimization of overhead and corporate costs. We expect to achieve up to €33 million of
operational synergies from the transfer of best practices within our group and from an increase in density as a
result of depot, merchandizer and technician network optimization and increase in utilization of telemetry
capabilities, which drives route efficiency for our refillers.

**_Continued Roll Out and Focus on Our Technology and Innovation Capabilities_**

We deem technology and innovation to be a competitive differentiator for our current operations and
business going forward. We continue to commit resources and make the necessary investments to be at the
forefront of technology and innovation in our industry. Currently, we are managing three footprint-wide key
enablers that contribute to an improvement in daily revenue per PoS and operational efficiency. Firstly, we are
expanding and upgrading our current PoS base with telemetry technology, a remote PoS monitoring allowing for
optimization of cost-to-serve and product availability while leading the transformation toward an end-to-end
operating model. Approximately 29% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019,
while we aim to roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. Secondly, we are also upgrading our
PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point of sale by providing access to
non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park
has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. Thirdly, our MicroMarket concept allows us to introduce an
innovative, unique, and attractive format bringing together technology, brands, and operational capabilities while
combining the classic vending model (convenience) with the cafeteria model (premium and healthy). While the
concept is already established in the UK, Italy, Switzerland and, recently, the Netherlands, we plan to roll-out the
format across our other markets to further expand our current footprint of 104 MicroMarkets as of June 30, 2019.
For example, we have launched our MicroMarket concept in Spain, where we have already entered into
agreements to install MicroMarkets, and in Germany, where we have started discussions with potential
customers.

**_Pursuing Growth Through a Disciplined Capital Expenditure Program_**

We intend to continue to pursue growth through a disciplined capital expenditure program that provides an
attractive return on investment period, while also optimizing the capital intensity of our operations. We have a
structured and consistent governance with respect to capital expenditures across our group, with pre-investments
business cases and post-investment appraisals and tracking of outcomes. At the same time, we are working to

114


-----

optimize the capital intensity of our operations by refurbishing existing PoS to increase their life and maximizing
our refurbishment capabilities and re-siting underperforming PoS. We also intend to continue exploring
off-balance sheet funding options, such as our alternative arrangements with Lavazza and other leasing
companies, to finance PoS investments for our customers, thereby reducing our initial investment cost for new
client contracts. Innovative route-based solutions such as MicroMarkets also have lower capital expenditure
requirements than classic impulse purchase offerings, while generating two to three times the revenue of a classic
self-service retail site, with each MicroMarket generating an approximate turnover of €50,000 annually. Through
these and other initiatives, we intend to reduce our PoS related cash capital expenditures to under €100.0 million
per year.

executing our strategies. To that end, we are undertaking initiatives related to performance management, sales
and operational capabilities, employee engagement and employer branding to ensure we maximize the potential
of our talent across our organization. Included among these initiatives are talent reviews of all teams to provide
improved management of the talent pools within each of our markets. We have developed a sales and operations
academy in order to train and develop our team with the right programs to drive customer satisfaction and
efficiencies. We have also worked to improve our employee on-boarding and performance management for our
field force, with a focus on developing first-line manager capabilities. In terms of employee engagement, we
have created a baseline employee survey in partnership with GALLUP, and plan to implement a tailored action

plan based on the survey results for each team. We are also focused on improving our internal communication
strategy, with improvement of our intranet, implementation of a new ethics program and the publishing of our
first CSR report. We believe that continued implementation of these initiatives, and a focus on the continued
development of our people, will support the execution of our strategies.

**Our History**

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown both organically as well as through acquisitions.
Following our first acquisition in Switzerland in 1959, we expanded into Germany in 1986, Sweden and France
in 1990, Austria, Slovakia and the Baltic countries in 1995, Belgium in 1997, Spain in 1998, the United Kingdom
and Ireland in 2001 and the Netherlands in 2004. In 1985, we were acquired by the Valora group, and, in 1997,
we listed on the SIX before de-listing in 2001. In 2001, we were acquired by the Compass group before
becoming part of Allianz Capital Partners through its acquisition of our business in 2007. We were acquired by
KKR in 2015.

In September 2017, we acquired the Pelican Rouge Group, previously known as Autobar Group Ltd, a
company incorporated in London in 1925, which engages in roasting and blending, packaging, and self-service
retail of coffee in the United Kingdom and internationally. In 2014, Autobar Group changed its name to Pelican
Rouge and relocated to Dordrecht, the Netherlands. The coffee brand Pelican Rouge (Roode Pelikaan) was
originally founded in 1863 in Antwerp.

In February 2018, we acquired the Argenta Group. Since its founding in Carpi, Modena, Italy in 1968, the
Argenta Group has grown organically as well as through acquisitions to become the second largest food and
beverage self-service retail operator in the Italian market. In 2016, the Argenta Group expanded into southern
Italy through the acquisition of Somed, and into the food retail business under the Foodie’s brand and through
agreements with 365 Retail Market with its MicroMarket concept.

In August 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium self-service retail
services with a focus on London and its neighboring counties. Express Vending’s offering of products and
services includes table top coffee machines and MicroMarkets. Express Vending was established in 1992 and is
headquartered in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, Great Britain. We also made three smaller acquisitions in
Italy in 2018.

**Our Business**

**_Overview of our Route-Based Operations_**

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider Europe by
revenue. We cover more than 3,800 routes reaching over ten million consumers with more than 475,000 PoS in
16 countries. As of June 30, 2019, our logistics set up was supported by approximately 150 planners, 4,900 route
merchandizers, 1,400 route technicians and a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. We pro-actively plan routes for our
merchandizers based on PoS consumption, capacity and other specific requirements, such as hygiene or customer
commitments. Our planning teams organize these visits by static route-planning with routes planned four to eight
weeks in advance based on historic consumption and internal tools, and by dynamic route-planning with daily
plans generated based on real-time data and forecasts collected from PoS through telemetry. We plan routes for
our technicians when one of our PoS experience a breakdown and, to a lesser extent, pro-actively to prevent any
issues.

Our operations span across the value chain of the self-service coffee and convenience food markets. We
purchase machines for our customers, or procure third party financing for our customers to purchase machines,
install them at their premises and manage the sourcing and stocking of the food and beverages on behalf of our
customers. We provide quality coffee brands and convenient food and beverage concepts, including premium
coffee concepts through our Starbucks and Lavazza partnerships. We also offer cleaning, maintenance and
technical support services, which can be customized to individual customers’ preferences. In addition to our selfservice retail operations, we sell self-service retail machines, machine parts and products independently of
service arrangements. We operate our PoS network under the “Selecta” brand across all our markets, except in
Italy where we use the “Argenta” brand and in Finland where we use the “Pelican Rouge” brand. We believe our
brands enjoy strong brand recognition in many of the markets in which we operate and stand for quality and
innovation.

**_Our Business Channels_**

Our self-service business serves consumers in the following business channels:

   - The workplace channel, which is comprised of (i) private self-service retail, consisting of PoS placed
and serviced in various private locations, such as large corporate customers, in various businesses and
industries and including in corporate offices, manufacturing and logistics sites and (ii) OCS, which is
comprised of table-top coffee machines rented out to corporate customers for office use along with the
provision of technical services and coffee and related supplies for the PoS. OCS is targeted primarily at
small and medium-sized enterprises.

   - The on-the-go channel, which is comprised of PoS placed and serviced in semi-public areas, or public
areas following a successful bidding process with relevant government authorities to place our PoS in a
given location. The types of public locations include train stations, airports and gas stations. The types
of semi-public locations include hospitals, universities and entertainment venues. The bidding process
by which we obtain our public contracts is long and contentious, and subject to many local laws and
ordinances. These contracts, however, are very lucrative to our business as these public spaces
experience high traffic during all hours in the day, including late nights when most other food and
beverage stores are closed for business. For example, we were able to grow our revenues in Germany
as a result of a public contract with Deutsche Bahn to place PoS throughout rail stations in the West
and South of Germany. Although the number of Selecta PoS used for public areas only represents 4%
of our PoS as of June 30, 2019, it accounts for 18% of our revenue for the twelve months ended
June 30, 2019.

   - The trading channel, which is comprised of sales of machines and products, including coffee roasted in
our roasting facility, as well as the provision of technical and hygienic support to customers.

**_Our Geographic Segments_**

As of June 30, 2019, we had combined operations in 16 countries across Europe. For operational,
management and financial reporting purposes, we divide our operations into the following three geographic
segments:

   - _South, UK & Ireland includes operating entities in Ireland, Italy, Spain and the UK;_

   - _Central includes operating entities in Austria, France, Germany, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland; and_

   - _North includes operating entities in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands,_
Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2017, one operating in Finland was classified as held for sale
and excluded from this segment; it was subsequently sold in March 2018.

**Our Products**

We provide customers with a range of mainstream to premium coffee and a variety of convenience food and
beverage products, including hot drinks, snacks, cold beverages, and filtered water, through a variety of table-top
coffee machines or free-standing PoS, coffee, cold beverages and snacks PoS and water dispensers. We also sell
coffee from our roasting facility, machines for hotels, restaurants and cafés (“HoReCa”), and machines directly
to customers or third parties independently of any services arrangements. Furthermore, through a partnership
agreement with 365 Retail, we operate MicroMarkets in Italy.

**_Hot Drinks Sold Through Our PoS_**

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, 56% of our revenue was generated by our variety of table top
and free-standing hot drink self-service PoS, with instant, roasted whole bean and ground coffee options,
professional espresso machines, and roasted coffee beans. These machines serve a wide variety of coffee and
coffee specialty drinks as well as freshly brewed tea, hot chocolate and soups. In 2009, we introduced our own
brand coffee blends under the Miofino brand to complement our range of hot drink self-service PoS. Following
the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, we have increased our range of own brand coffee offerings under the name
Pelican Rouge. Both Pelican Rouge and Miofino coffee offerings include mild, medium, and bold blends as well
as decaffeinated and organic and fair trade-certified blends, including instant, roasted whole bean and ground
coffee options. Specific Pelican Rouge and Miofino coffee blend availability varies according to country.

Table top machines are primarily targeted at the private self-service retail segment, such as offices, but are
also frequently located in restaurants and cafés and in certain specific public locations such as gas stations. Free

standing PoS, in contrast, are primarily suited for public locations in high-traffic areas such as airports and train
and subway stations. We offer table top and free-standing models on either free vend basis, where the customer
covers the cost of the products and users do not need to pay at the PoS, or pay vend basis, where consumers
purchase items using coins or a form of cashless payment systems. See “—Payment Options.” Our wide selection
of hot drink self-service PoS allows customers to select the right machine for their needs based on additional
factors, such as cup capacity and the number of available drink selections. For example, our Ferrara coffee selfservice machine has capacity for 100 cups per day, can vend a variety of coffee specialties, in addition to freshly
brewed tea and hot chocolate. It also features an integrated color touch screen that allows users to select and
customize their drinks by adding sugar or increasing or decreasing the strength of drinks to taste, and nutritional
and allergy information is available via the touch screen to help consumers make informed choices.

**_Roasted Coffee Produced by Our Roasting Facility_**

We operate a roasting facility in Dordrecht, the Netherlands, from which we supply the Group and third
parties, such as wholesale businesses, other self-service retailers, and industrial customers in over 65 countries,
with coffee. While the primary focus of the facility is producing roasted whole bean and ground coffee, which
accounted for 44% of our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, it also mixes
instant coffee products, in each case under the Pelican Rouge brand, which accounted for 56% of our Adjusted

-----

Revenue (CS & CC) over the same period. Within the capsule, roasted whole bean, ground and instant coffee
categories, customers may choose among a wide selection of arabica or robusta, and caffeinated or decaf roasts
of varying strengths, some of which are certified organic. The typical customers for these products include retail
and food self-service chains, hotels, restaurants, and cafés. Revenue generated from the roasting facility is
accounted for within our trade segment.

**_Snacks, Cold Drinks and Non-Food Items Sold Through Our PoS_**

We offer a range of free-standing PoS for snacks, cold drinks, or a combination of the two. Each PoS can be
configured as a free vend or pay vend PoS, with pay vend PoS being accompanied by a choice of various
cashless payment systems.

Our snack, cold drinks and combination PoS are primarily differentiated by their product capacity. For
example, each of our Santa Fe touch and Santa Fe XL machine models are equipped to vend snacks,
confectionary items, cans, bottles and tetra packs, and their flexible layouts allow for easy reconfiguration to
accommodate changes in product offering or layout, i.e. snacks and cold beverage combination in the warm
months and snacks and hot beverage combination in the colder months. Through the electronic shelf labels and
the touchscreen of the Santa Fe Touch, we can ensure accurate and up-to-date price, allergy, and nutrition
information is provided to the consumers. We generally offer customers a standard assortment of brand name and
top sellers snacks and beverages, but the product mix can also be tailored to the customer’s needs to reflect, for
example, particular regional tastes in snack foods or drinks as well as locally-sourced items.

Our newest glass-fronted cold drinks machines, such as the St. Tropez, include a modern cooling system
which concentrates the air flow at the front of the shelves in order to provide the next drinks to be dispensed at
the optimum temperature, and ensures a shake-free delivery at an ergonomic height. They also feature an
integrated robotic lift, which delivers the selected drink to the carousel within ten seconds, and use energy-saving
LED lights. These machines can be programmed to automatically switch off the illumination or reduce the chiller
outside of working hours.

In addition, our PoS typically feature separators, which can be easily removed for cleaning and separate
access to payment systems.

**_Water Dispensers_**

Our water dispensers are primarily suited for offices and other private settings. Our water dispensers use tap
water with integrated filtration systems to control water quality, allow the water temperature to be adjusted and,
depending on the type of dispenser, offer multiple water dispensing options—unchilled, medium chilled or
chilled still water and medium or highly carbonated soda water. Additionally, flavor concentrates can be installed
inside the water dispenser unit to provide flavored water.

**_HoReCa Product Range_**

HoReCa are products offered historically by Pelican Rouge and targeted at hospitality professionals, such as
food self-service chains, hotels and restaurants. HoReCa products are fully automatic, table top dispensers
suitable for high use environments that provide a wide variety of hot drinks, such as espressos, cappuccinos, hot
chocolates and teas. These products have a distinctive and refined aesthetic appeal, which is a key factor in this
segment. Our line of HoReCa products and services are differentiated on cup capacity and efficiency, multibeverage optionality and flexibility, allowing our customers to select a model that is ideally suited to their
particular environment and the taste and preferences of their consumers.

**_MicroMarkets_**

MicroMarkets, which are unmanned and unattended, self-service convenience stores designed for the
workplace in companies with over 200 employees, are a recent addition to our product offering. These
MicroMarkets provide a wide product range, including fresh products, coffee, drinks and snacks, and are a lowercost alternative for consumers to office cafeterias with similar offerings and limited times of operation.
Alternatively, the self-checkout system in MicroMarkets is available 24 hours a day. MicroMarkets offer a
greater variety of products than traditional self-service retail, specifically fresh foods offerings, such as
sandwiches or fruits, and innovative and healthy snacks and drinks. MicroMarkets allow us to sell products in
various formats and sizes and offer an innovative and digital consumer experience through the ability to touch
products and read labels and the advanced checkout process, while requiring significantly lower capital
expenditures compared with traditional PoS with impulse offerings and less complex operational and planning
requirements of cafeterias.

**_Machines, Machine Parts and Products_**

We also sell new and unwanted used machines, machine parts and products to customers and third parties,
including self-service retail operators, separately and independent of service arrangements. Certain customers
contract with us for the supply of products to stock existing machines on their premises. Revenue generated from
such sales is accounted for within our trade segment. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, revenue from

**Our Services**

In conjunction with our range of PoS for our workplace and on-the-go channels, we offer three categories of
services to meet our customers’ needs: full services package, partial service package, and supply/technical
services.

**_Full Service Package_**

Our full service package is our most comprehensive self-service retail concept. It includes installation of
PoS, regular filling and cleaning of PoS, as well as cash collection and technical maintenance. In addition, daily
or weekly visits ensure that our customers’ PoS are well-maintained, functioning properly and frequently stocked
with fresh products, including new product introductions. Under our full services package, we pay a fee to our
customer based on sold cups or a flat fee, and we directly collect the proceeds of the sales from the PoS.

**_Partial Service Package_**

Our partial service concept primarily targets smaller office environments. Under this package, we provide
the PoS and the ingredients to the customer in exchange for a monthly fee or vending fee. The customer is
responsible for cleaning and refilling the PoS. We primarily offer our partial services package to address the OCS
segment.

**_Supply/Technical Services_**

We also offer our technical support services under separate contracts negotiated with the customer, and
these can be combined with our other services to meet the customers’ specific needs.

**Payment Options**

Our pay vend PoS allow for a range of payment options from traditional cash payments with coins to
cashless and mobile payment technologies. These include employee cash cards and keys, bank cards and credit
cards, corporate cashless payment systems and mobile phone payments, including Selecta eWallet, which we
introduced in the summer 2018 as a lower cost (to us) alternative to other contactless payment systems, and the
Argenta App (described below). Cash card and key options are relatively common among our PoS located in
offices or other private points of sale due to the ability to set different prices for different consumers, such as
company personnel and visitors. As the growth in the use of alternative payment methods accelerates, credit card
and mobile phone payment options are more frequently included in our PoS located at publicly accessible points
of sale. We have also started to add alternative payment methods to our paid vend PoS in semi-public and private
sites. Cashless payment options help to support sales from PoS and enable higher average spend of consumers
than cash transactions. We have, therefore, updated our Selecta app and Selecta eWallet, to function not only as a
tool to locate our PoS, but also as a method of payment at certain of our PoS, including all public PoS in
Switzerland and approximately 8,000 PoS in Italy. Similarly, in addition to being a cashless method of payment,
the Argenta App is designed to feature a variety of promos and a loyalty program to incentivize the repeated use
of Argenta’s PoS. As of June 30, 2019, we had approximately 42,287 cashless devices.

Certain customers in our private channel make our PoS available to their employees on a free vend or
partially subsidized basis. This is particularly true for office coffee machines and is more common among our
customers in Northern European and Scandinavian countries.

**Competition and Market Position**

The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We
are one of the very few self-service retail operators active on a pan-European level. We are the leading routebased unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by revenue, with operations in
16 countries across Europe. We compete with regional players in Europe such as Kaffeepartner, Dallmayr, IVS

120


-----

and Daltys, among others, and with Nespresso and JDE and other OCS providers, in our workplace business
channel. In addition, we compete against a large number of small players that operate a few PoS on a local or
regional basis, particularly in our workplace channel. See “Industry and Market Data” and “Risk Factors—Risks
_Related to Our Business—We operate in a highly competitive market, and if we do not compete effectively, we_
_may lose market share or be unable to maintain or increase prices for our products and services.”_

**Customers and Consumers**

**_Customers_**

We serve a large base of public, semi-public and private customers, including companies, manufacturing,
logistics, and office environments, hospitals and universities, hotels, restaurants and cafés, as well as networks of
gas stations, airports, train and subway stations. We broadly segregate our customers into workplace and
on-the-go customers. Our customers in our North region are predominantly workplace coffee focused, while our
Central region customers are on-the-go focused, and our South, UK, and Ireland region customers are
predominantly comprised of private customers. We aim to further expand our customer base and, for example,
we have recently won or renewed contracts with Madrid Airport in Spain, Amsterdam UMC hospital and the
National Police in the Netherlands, Texaco (fuel provider) in Belgium, Volvo (car manufacturer) in Sweden,
Welcome Break (motorway services operator) and Coca Cola European Partners in the UK and the Pathé
Gaumont Cinema chain in France.

For public customers and, to a very limited extent, large private customers, we generally pay vending fees to
place our PoS on their premises. Vending fee arrangements include fixed or variable fees (based on a percentage
of revenue from vends) as well as a combination of the two. They are based on a number of factors, including
tender specifications for public bids, competitive pressure, contract length, offers by competitors, expected
revenue, locations and the demographics of the relevant locations. Our extended experience in the self-service
retail operator industry provides us with insight to help determine competitive yet prudent vending fee levels.
Vending fees are typically higher for countries with a higher share of public PoS in their portfolio, given that
these fees refer to the consideration paid to customers for the use of their premises.

In addition to originating new customer business, our sales teams coordinate and monitor the renewal of
customer contracts and the public tenders in which we participate. Approximately an average of 20% of our
contracts are up for renewal each year. In our private self-service retail operations (including our OCS services),
typical customer contract terms range from three to five years. Our contracts with public customers are
frequently longer, typically ranging from five to ten years. Our customer contracts typically provide us with the
exclusive right to install and operate PoS on our customer’s premises, although certain contracts with public
customers do not include such exclusivity rights. Our customer contracts generally automatically renew for a
period of one or two years at the end of the initial term in the absence of notice of termination. The notice period
for termination of customer contracts is typically three or six months for each contracting party. In the event of a
breach of contract that has not been remedied within one month from the provision of notice of the breach, our
customer contracts commonly allow for termination by the non-breaching party at any time.

We believe our reputation for quality products, innovation and customer service has enabled us to form
strong and long lasting customer relationships across a broad range of customers. We believe this is also evident
in our overall average customer retention rate. We estimate that our retention rate was approximately 95.9% for
the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, without taking into account the Express Vending Acquisition, which is
an increase of approximately 1.8% compared to the same period in 2018.

**_Consumers_**

Food and beverages available from our PoS are purchased by individuals who consume such items during
breaks, as in-between meals in their offices, at recreational or educational facilities, in hospitals, schools,
government buildings, while on-the-go on public transportation, at airports or at highway service or gas stations.
As a result, we devote significant resources to the consumer experience and specifically to maintaining our PoS
and keeping them clean, updated and well-stocked with international brand-name and local products that appeal
to a variety of demographics and palettes. Furthermore, we leverage the data we collect through telemetry to
tailor our offering of drinks and snacks in each location based on local consumer preferences in order to enhance
the consumer experience with our PoS.

**Procurement**

Our Group procurement department is responsible for negotiating contracts for various products and stock,
which are used uniformly throughout the Group. Such items include machines, coffee, sugar, cups, stirrers and
other ancillary products. In purchasing these products at the Group level, we are able to leverage our size to
obtain better terms than our smaller regional competitors. Certain other items, such as confectionary products and
machine spare parts, and the organization of logistics related to such items generally remain the responsibility of
our local procurement departments at the country level.

**_Product Suppliers_**

We purchase our supplies and stock from a number of suppliers, including from private label suppliers as
well as brand name producers such as Coca-Cola, Danone, Lavazza, Mars, Mondelez, Nestlé, Pepsi and
Starbucks. We purchase the green coffee beans used for our coffee roasting business from Mercon Europe SL,
Supremo SA, Ecom Agroindustrial Corp. Ltd., Bernard Rothfos GmbH and Coffeeteam SA, and most volume is
sourced from Brazil, Vietnam and Colombia. We choose our suppliers carefully and value maintaining a broad
supplier base. For significant portions of our purchasing volumes, we generally enter into framework agreements
with our suppliers pursuant to which products and materials, quality standards, terms and prices are specified.
Such framework agreements typically have terms of three years. Due to the extensive variety of types and brands
of food and drinks we can offer in our PoS, we are not faced with supplier concentration.

122


-----

**_Machine Suppliers_**

We purchase and lease our machines from 16 key suppliers, including Franke for our premium hot drink
machines, WMF for coffee machines, Evoca Group for our mainstream hot drink machines, Crane MS and
Sielaff for our combination public machines and Borg & Overström for our water dispensers, with no single
supplier representing more than 30% of total PoS capital expenditures. We purchase or lease a variety of
different models of machines depending on, among others, the market, concept, product volumes, and the
customer’s requirements. See “—Real Estate and Equipment.” We purchase our machines in the currency of the
supplier to limit our foreign exchange exposure. As of June 30, 2019, we owned approximately 78% of the PoS
in our active PoS park, while the remainder were operated through leases.

**_Refurbishment Capability_**

As part of our strategy to improve our offering and deliver the best self-service and convenience solutions to
our customers and consumers, from time to time we upgrade our public PoS with a new appearance. We have
two primary refurbishment facilities for such purposes located in Milan and Madrid, with a third smaller site in
Dordrecht. While the majority of the refurbishments are processed in one of our three refurbishment facilities, in
cases where the shipping costs for the amount of work required are prohibitive, we use external providers in the
local market. Collectively, our refurbishment plants and external providers can upgrade or repair approximately
30,000 PoS per year. As a result of the Argenta Acquisition, we have gained new and more cost-effective
methods of refurbishment. Refurbishing and upgrading existing PoS can save up to 70% of capital expenditures
when compared to buying a new PoS.

**Innovation**

We are continuously upgrading and improving our PoS park with the latest technology. Telemetry devices
provide real-time sale information from our PoS to remote data collection points. We can then use this data to
improve our product selection for each PoS and our over-all business strategy based on major trends. We also
incur lower service costs by collecting such data as we avoid unnecessary trips to already well-stocked PoS.
Additionally, real time inventory monitoring allows us to avoid stock-outs and lost sales. Approximately 29% of
our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded with telemetry devices as of June 30, 2019, while we aim to
roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. The number of PoS that include telemetry devices has
increased to 65,813 as of June 30, 2019, from 9,643, 21,573, and 41,612 as of September 30, 2016, 2017 and
2018, respectively.

We are also upgrading our PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point
of sale by providing access to non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Among other
cashless payment options, consumers can choose to pay with their smart-phones through our apps, including the
Selecta eWallet or the Argenta App. See “—Payment Options.” We have been steadily increasing the number of
our PoS equipped with cashless payments, with a cost of approximately €150 to €300 to upgrade each PoS,
depending on the type of payment system and PoS, and approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park has already
been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we had approximately 42,287 cashless devices,
primarily located in public locations.

**Sales, Marketing and Customer Service**

Our sales and marketing activities are largely organized on a decentralized basis. While our best practices,
brand guidelines and sales and marketing concepts are developed centrally at our office in Cham, Switzerland,
the implementation of such practices and concepts is conducted at the country level. Similarly, the organization
of our sales and marketing teams varies by country. In some countries, particularly the smaller countries in which
we operate, the head functions in sales and marketing are combined in one role. In larger countries, we typically
have distinct sales and marketing directors responsible for the respective activities, including setting the budgets
and oversight of small teams of sales and marketing representatives focused on our customers and services in that
country. At a Group level, we incentivize our sales force to focus on increasing turnover contribution margins,
contract length, and customer retention. Following the integration of the Pelican Rouge Group and the Argenta
Group, we have developed strategic initiatives to increase sales efficiency (particularly in France and in the UK),
such as increased focus on customer satisfaction, systematic approach to gathering customer feedback,
introduction of training and incentivizing staff based on customer satisfaction and local sales team offering
specifically tailored propositions to new customers. We have rolled out a strategic sales acceleration program in
Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK as a result of these initiatives.

123


-----

Our private customers frequently come to us through a combination of channels. The Selecta and Pelican
Rouge brand names are among the largest self-service retail companies in the market and potential new
customers may contact us directly. However, we have structured lead generation processes in place, where leads
can be generated from visit to our websites, prospects entered into our CRM tool, incoming calls to our customer
service/telesales departments and also sales force cold calling/visits. The main focus of our local marketing teams
is lead generation. In addition, larger private companies tender their services and we are usually invited to these
tenders. Our cooperation and framework agreements with facility management also provide us with new
customers and leads.

We have developed for our sales team a central program coordination team with strong local capabilities
and support to help harmonize prices in all of our markets. We differentiate prices by applying segmentation and
deploying segment specific and location specific price strategies and to monitor and analyzing sales data
collected through telemetry, in order to formulate pricing strategies for each category of products in each market,
we then focus on price strategies for the top ten popular products in each market. Our telemetry data also allows
for a dynamic pricing strategy, which is capable of adapting to consumer reactions in real time. In the
business-to-business to consumer space we have implemented margin management on underperforming accounts
and systematic annual price increases in addition to price differentiation between brand and non-brand items; in
the business-to-business space, we have implemented similar systematic annual price increases, in addition to
upselling products such as premium coffee and reducing leakage.

We continually aim to provide efficient and effective customer care. Our business operates with the support
of service call centers in each country, which accept inbound calls for PoS malfunctions and maintenance issues,
and sales call centers, which place outbound calls to generate sales of our OCS and machine products and
services. Our relevant call centers’ telephone numbers are displayed on all of our PoS, allowing customers or
consumers to directly get in touch with us for a quick resolution of any maintenance or other technical issues. In
addition, inbound calls received by customers can be directed to technicians to help customers troubleshoot or
resolve technical issues in order to avoid the need for, and time and expense associated with, a site visit. We
improved our average of serviced PoS per technician from 264 for the year ended September 30, 2017 (after
giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition) to 269 over the same period in 2018.

**Information Technology**

Our IT operations have historically been performed primarily on a decentralized basis. In particular, IT
functions related to matters such as procurement, tracking and logistics have largely been managed at the country
level, supported by four teams of IT personnel located in Switzerland, Spain, the Netherlands, France and the
United Kingdom. We continue to invest in our IT systems in order to maintain and enhance our overall business
processes. We use IT solutions in nearly all phases of our operations, from procuring machines, spare parts and
products to monitoring operational processes and tracking logistics and maintenance of our machines.

Furthermore, certain IT systems acquired through the Argenta Acquisition support and facilitate the use and
development of various applications, information streams, and other services that are vital to the efficiency of
business operations. This includes, among others, field service management, supply chain management, business
sales, and finance. We have a dedicated IT department in Italy, with the capability to assist our Italian operations
on all software-related projects.

We have undertaken a detailed assessment of our IT infrastructure, systems, and applications and are
currently in the process of implementing an enhanced IT architecture with a more centralized focus, in particular
with respect to core applications.

**Real Estate and Equipment**

We conduct our operations primarily through PoS that we own. We own or lease a combination of
warehouses and regional and branch offices in many of the countries in which we operate. Our properties are
typically leased for fixed terms of between five and 20 years. In general, our lease agreements can be terminated
at our option prior to the maturity date, in certain cases with a penalty. We believe that our properties meet our
present needs and that they are sufficiently maintained and suitable for their intended use. Additionally, we have
started to lease our coffee roasting plant in the Netherlands since September 2019, pursuant to a sale and
leaseback transaction in respect of all lands and buildings of our roasting facility. The term of the lease, in line
with our other lease agreements, is 20 years.

With respect to other fixed assets, we owned and operated more than 475,000 PoS as of June 30, 2019, and a
fleet of over 5,000 vehicles dedicated to restocking our PoS. Depending on the country, we either purchase or

124


-----

lease our vehicles through finance or operating leases. We believe our equipment is in good condition and
suitable for our operations and their intended use.

We depreciate our free-standing hot drink PoS over a period of six years, table top machines over a period
of four years, and snack and cold drink PoS over a period of eight years. However, we are generally able to
utilize our PoS beyond such four or eight year period, with table top machines lasting up to eight years and snack
and cold drink PoS lasting up to 20 years, with the appropriate refurbishment. We continually refurbish and
upgrade some of our PoS to extend their useful life. For example, public PoS can be refurbished twice, tripling
their useful life. PoS that are not refurbished and redeployed are either sold or scrapped. The typical cost of a
refurbished PoS is approximately 30% to 40% that of a new PoS, which can vary widely depending on the level
of refurbishment required.

**_Pension and Benefits_**

We operate various pension and retirement schemes in accordance with local conditions and practices in the
countries in which we operate. We have defined contribution plans in place for certain employees in Belgium,
Denmark, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom and defined benefit
plans for certain employees in Belgium, Finland, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom.
These pension plans provide for the payment of retirement and certain survivor benefits. Benefits payable under
these plans are determined on the basis of any employee’s length of service, earnings and position. Under the
defined benefit plans, employees are entitled to retirement benefits equal to a percentage of their accumulated
savings in the plan on reaching a locally defined retirement age. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our
employee benefits expense increased by 10.2% from the previous year.

We also operate a management remuneration bonus policy, which is designed to attract and retain quality
people and to be in line with, or above, market standards. The terms and conditions of our management
remuneration bonus policy are determined at our headquarters and are consistent across the Group. We have
designed this policy to facilitate communication of annual goals to be achieved in each management band.

**_Collective Bargaining Agreements_**

The countries in which we operate provide various protections and bargaining or other rights to employees.
These employment rights may require us to expend greater time and costs in negotiating or amending employees’
terms of employment or making staff reductions.

We have collective bargaining agreements in place with our employees in Finland, Italy, the Netherlands,
Sweden and France. In Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain and Sweden, we have works councils
in place, which are representative bodies for our employees and through which we agree changes in conditions of
employment, such as working hours, salary levels and benefits. We consider our relations with the works
councils to be good.

generally address matters such as minimum wage, salary adjustments, working hours, breaks and vacation and

**Insurance**

We maintain general liability, property, directors’ and officers’, business interruption and other insurance
policies with coverage limits we consider consistent with industry practice. The terms of our customer contracts
typically provide that the customer will ensure that the PoS placed on its premises are insured against third party
claims and carry certain insurance protection against damage or vandalism, whether as part of its general
insurance policies or insured separately. Our other fixed assets, such as our office buildings, technical equipment
used in distribution, restocking and PoS refurbishment, information technology and office equipment, are
protected by a bundled industrial insurance policy (damages from fire, catastrophes, theft, flood and severe
weather) that includes a business interruption insurance when business interruption is caused by an insured
property damage. We monitor our insurance policies to ensure that we remain in compliance with any conditions
thereunder.

We consider our insurance coverage to be adequate both as to the nature of the risks covered and amounts
insured for our business operations and review our coverage on a periodic basis. However, there can be no
